editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A TOKEN FOR MARINERS, CONTAINING Many Famous and Wonderful InÅ¿tances of God's Providence in Sea Dangers and Deliverances, in Mercifully preÅ¿erving the Lives of his poor Creatures, when, in Humane Probability, at the Point of PeriÅ¿hing by Shipwrack, Famine, or other Accidents.
Much Enlarg'd, with the Addition of many New Relations, one whereof happening this PreÅ¿ent Year, and never before Printed. MoÅ¿tly Attested by the PerÅ¿ons ThemÅ¿elves.
ALSO The Seaman's Preacher, Being a Sermon on the Right Improvement of Å¿uch MERCIES. And Prayers for Seamen on all OccaÅ¿ions.
LONDON, Printed by Hugh Newman, and Sold at his Shop at the GraÅ¿hopper in the Poultry. 1698.

div.head: THE Preface to the Reader. And Particularly to Mariners, and other Seafaring-Men.
div.p:
THough God's Wonders are every where viÅ¿ible, and his Mercies no where hid from the Eyes of Men; yet more particularly are they Evident to Sea-faring Men, whoÅ¿e BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s is in the Great Waters, and their Lives ExpoÅ¿ed more than others to Iunumerable hazards and dangers, of Contending Winds and Seas, Rocks, QuickÅ¿ands, and InhoÅ¿pitable Shoaers: TheÅ¿e, as it were, carry their Lives in their hands, and their beÅ¿t Security is Wholly to Rely on the Providence and Protection of him whoÅ¿e Power the Winds and Waves obey: Seeing there is Å¿o Å¿mall a partition between them and Eternity, the Striking on a Treacherous Rock, over which, many times, the Flattering Water Å¿moothly glides, gives them their
Winding-Å¿heet in a Rumpled Wave. Nor is this all their danger, the Springing of a Plank, a Leak not to be found, nor Å¿uddenly Å¿topped, Running on a Shoal, or the Falling of a Water-Å¿pout, frequently carry with them the Å¿ame Inevitable Fate, and often makes them at their Wits Ends before they end their Lives; for, a certain ProÅ¿pect of Æ²navoidable Death muÅ¿t needs be Terrible to FleÅ¿h and Blood, and, in a great meaÅ¿ure, remove that ConÅ¿tant PreÅ¿ence of Mind that Å¿hould Å¿upport their Spirits amidÅ¿t all Dangers: From this there is no way to Å¿ecure themÅ¿elves, but by laying hold on him that is Mighty, and able to Å¿ave to the utmoÅ¿t, on God, who is a preÅ¿ent help at need, whoÅ¿e eyes are in all places, in Heaven and Earth, and in the Great Deep; and thoÅ¿e that Cry to him in their DiÅ¿treÅ¿s, he will Å¿urely hear them and Deliver them out of all their Troubles, if they are Å¿incere in heart, and walk uprightly with him. For a Praying-Paul's Å¿ake, we find, though the Ship was broken, and periÅ¿hed on a Rock on the CoaÅ¿t of the IÅ¿land, antiently Melita, now called Malta, all that were in it were Å¿aved, when they expected nothing leÅ¿s than to be Å¿wallowed up in that dangerous Ocean, as we find it in the Acts, Chap. 27. Therefore the beÅ¿t thing I can Recommend to Mariners, and others that Navigate
the Deep, is to have a Å¿tedfaÅ¿t Relyance on God in all their Dangers, nay, at all times, for that is the beÅ¿t and Å¿ureÅ¿t Anchor-hold and Security that can be had recourÅ¿e to, and therefore I have furniÅ¿hed this Book with many Wonderful and Remarkable Sea-Deliverances, to Å¿how them that their hopes are not in vain; for, the Wonders he has already wrought, he will doubtleÅ¿s continue to all that fear and put their TruÅ¿t in him.

This Collection is taken moÅ¿tly from the Mouths of thoÅ¿e who have experienc'd God's Mercy this way, and whoÅ¿e Dangers have been as great as any could be on this Å¿ide the Grave; yet God, in his Mercy, delivered them out of all. The reÅ¿t are taken from Å¿uch Reverend Authors, that their Credit and Integrity is IndiÅ¿putable, being purpoÅ¿ely Written to raiÅ¿e the Minds of Men to Contemplate and Adore the Love and GoodneÅ¿s of the All-wiÅ¿e Creator of the Æ²niverÅ¿e, and may indifferently Å¿erve to this end as well at Land as Sea, though chiefly intended for Sea-faring Men, to put them in Mind, when they Read it, of their Danger, and what they may expect in their Danger, from the Death they apprehend in it, if they apply their hearts to true WiÅ¿dom. When all help or hopes fail, or Å¿eem to be at a loÅ¿s, then fix your hearts and eyes Å¿tedfaÅ¿tly on him who is
able to do all things, and to whom nothing is impoÅ¿Å¿ible; on him, in whoÅ¿e hands is all the Breath of Life, who can Å¿top the Å¿hafts of Death in their winged motion, check the Bellowing Thunder in the Midd-Volley, and turn the Raging of the Winds to a Å¿udden Calm.

But not to be Tedious in a Preface; I recommend this to you, as a Å¿uitable Companion in your Voyages or Travels, nay in your houÅ¿es, or at all times, that you may know theÅ¿e things are the Lord's doing, tho they are Marvellous in our eyes. And Å¿o Conclude, Å¿ubÅ¿cribing my Å¿elf,

closer.signed: Your Friend and Servant, J. J.

div.head: REMARKABLE SEA Deliverances.
div.p:
ONe Major Gibbons, a man well known in new England, a Gentleman of good education, good parts, and of good ConverÅ¿ation, (as the Author hath been credibly informed by them that knew him) was bound upon a voyage to Sea, himÅ¿elf being Supra Cargo with Å¿uch commoditys as thoÅ¿e parts of America doth afford, after going out from BoÅ¿ton Å¿everal days, by hard weather, and contrary winds, the Ships company were much diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed, and through the Continuance of the contrary winds ProviÅ¿ions now begin to faile them; and O how feeble doth Spirit
grow, when Bread, the Staffe of life faileth! now Hunger becomes more dreadfull to them, then the every moment threatning Billows of the devouring Ocean; and they that one while feared drowning, now fears Starving; they are brought to the laÅ¿t meal in the Barrel, and the laÅ¿t oyl in the CruÅ¿e, and Å¿ay as Å¿he did We will Eat this little that is left, and dye: and now when they thought they had eaten the laÅ¿t, what conflicts muÅ¿t they needs have within themÅ¿elves? who knew not where to have another morÅ¿el to fortify the tyred and Å¿pent Spirits with the conÅ¿tant toyl, and hard labour: how they look one upon another, as men already under a Sentence of death; and by one anothers looks, Strike terror to one anothers Hearts; They look on every Å¿ide, PÅ¿al. 142. 4, 5. (as David Å¿ays) I looked on my right hand, but there was no man that would know me; Refuge failed me; or periÅ¿hed from me. They look downward, and Å¿ee nothing but the Belly of deÅ¿truction opening for them; they look upward, the onely, and laÅ¿t refuge, and remedy, in this deplorable eÅ¿tate was, out of the depths, they cry'd to the Lord,

But though they look out of the Ship, as Noah did out of his Ark, upon the waters
and Å¿end forth the Dove of Prayer, that winged MeÅ¿Å¿enger, to Heaven, yet Å¿he brings no Olive branch, no AnÅ¿wer; the waters aÅ¿Å¿wage not, the winds calm not, they are like the Prophets Servant, when he bid him 1 Kings 18. 43. go up now; and look to-wards the Sea, and he went up and looked and Å¿aid, there is nothing; and this Å¿trikes them into dolefull and diÅ¿mall Lamentations; out of which Lamentations, at laÅ¿t Springs up a tragical and Å¿orrowfull Motion. The Motion is, that which the Marriners, in Jonahs VeÅ¿Å¿el, put in execution, Come let us caÅ¿t Lots, &c. only with this difference, they caÅ¿t Lots to find out the dilinquent; and theÅ¿e, which of them Å¿hould dye firÅ¿t, to be a Sacrifice for ravenous Hunger to feed upon: Concluding, as he in that caÅ¿e, John. 11. 50. It is expedient for us that one man Å¿hould dye for the People, and that the whole Ships Company periÅ¿h not. Life being Å¿weet, Skin for Skin, and all a man hath will he give for his life, they at laÅ¿t bring it, through many a Å¿ad debate, to a reÅ¿ult, they caÅ¿t the Lott, the diÅ¿poÅ¿ing of which is of the Lord; one of the Company is arreÅ¿ted by the Lott; here is the Condemned PriÅ¿oner: O but where is the Executioner to be found to act his office upon a poor Innocent? is it not
death to them now, to think who Å¿hall act this bloody part in the Tragedy? But before they fall upon their involuntary Execution, Major Gibbons calls them to Prayer, conÅ¿idering, that in the Mount, the Lord is often Å¿een, and that many times our extremity proves Gods opportunity; he alÅ¿o askes the poor man if he was willing to dye; but O what a hard QueÅ¿tion is that to AnÅ¿wer! He replys, if it might preÅ¿erve the reÅ¿t of the lives, he could be the more willing; to which he hath this AnÅ¿wer: All events are in the hands of God, we muÅ¿t not diÅ¿pute them, to Prayer they go: and, O Å¿ure theÅ¿e Prayers muÅ¿t melt hearts of Adamant! and Behold, while they are at it, God Å¿ends a viÅ¿ible commentary upon that Scripture: EÅ¿ay 58. 9. Then Å¿halt thou call, and the Lord Å¿hall AnÅ¿wer; thou Å¿halt Cry, and he Å¿hall Å¿ay here I am: For while they were calling, God was AnÅ¿wering; there leaps a mighty FiÅ¿h into the Boat; and as it is Å¿aid of the Whale: that Å¿wallowed up Jonah, God prepared a FiÅ¿h, for the Lord here prepared, or provided a FiÅ¿h, that a poor creature might not be Å¿wallowed up: but O what joy was here at Å¿uch a token for good! not only it at preÅ¿ent releiving and refreÅ¿hing their huuger, which no QueÅ¿ton
made them quick Cooks; but when they looked upon the Finger of God in it, Å¿ending it as an anÅ¿wer to prayer, they conclude it an happy Omen of their deliverance, and a pledg of approaching mercy: but alas, it is not long before their hearts grow faint again, their Countenances pale, their Spirits Å¿ink now as low as they were lifted up high; and now the poor Sea-men are like their Ship, one while mounted up in the hopes to Heaven, and another while they are Å¿unk down again in deÅ¿pair as low as hell; they know not now of another cake, another MorÅ¿ell, they are reduced to their former exigency, which brings them to a reÅ¿olve to Å¿teer in this Å¿trait their old courÅ¿e; to Lotts they go again the Second time, only they have Å¿uch an honour for the Providence of God, they will not put him into condemnation, that God hath acquited; the Lott now falls upon another perÅ¿on, and O now they receive the old trouble, and inteÅ¿tine Combats, how they Å¿hall find in their Hearts, to puniÅ¿h one, that never had offended any of them; and while one thinks of it, Å¿ayes he, Alas poor man, what hath he done to deÅ¿erve this Å¿entence? another crys, Will not this blood cleave to my ConÅ¿cience another day? though I went to this expedition
a PreÅ¿t Souldier? another Å¿ays, for his part he Å¿ees no way but death, therefore he cannot take away life, when he Å¿ees not any life can be preÅ¿erved by it: but they are called again to look upward, before they put the Knife to the Throat of this Sacrifice, and they remember the laÅ¿t encouragement to put life into the almoÅ¿t dead-mens Prayers; they pray now with a pledge in their hands, and are ready to tell God, the laÅ¿t time he gave them a Pawn, an EarneÅ¿t; and O it is not vain to Å¿eek the Lord! for lo â¢ , while they are Å¿eeking to him, he is Å¿ending to them; as the Prayers flye to Heaven, Mercy is diÅ¿patched upon the wing from Heaven.

O turn aÅ¿ide, and Å¿ee this great Å¿ight, while they are praying. Behold a Å¿econd AnÅ¿wer from above; A great Bird lights and fixes her Å¿elf upon the MaÅ¿t, which one in the Company eÅ¿pies, and up he goes and there Å¿he Å¿tands until he took her with his hand by the wing, & brought her down to the Company; and O what life from the dead is this to them a Å¿econd time! Sure they will hearken to the voyce of the Å¿econd Sign, if not to the voyce of the firÅ¿t; and now that which they hoped by the firÅ¿t Providence (viz) that it was a fore-runner of the compleat deliverance; Now they are by this Å¿econd confirmed
in the Faith, and now they begin to think (as I can eaÅ¿ily imagin) if God will Å¿ave them out of this diÅ¿treÅ¿s, O what manner of perÅ¿ons they will become! what manner of lives they will live! what Sacrifices of ThankÅ¿giving will they offer up to God! but while they are thus thinking they have no viÅ¿ible hopes, but that it muÅ¿t be a third Miracle that brings them out of this their miÅ¿erable condition; they have the Å¿ame diÅ¿appointments upon them Å¿till, only now they divert their Hunger all they can, by telling of, and remembring the Loaves, (as I may Å¿ay) their experiences in this extremity of theirs, and comforting themÅ¿elves, that if they come to a third Å¿trait, it would (they hoped) be an outlet from their preÅ¿ent miÅ¿ery and calamity: They are reduced the third time to the former courÅ¿e and Å¿trait, to caÅ¿t Lotts; and when they were to go to the heart-aking work, to put him to death, upon whom the Lott fell, they go to their Old Friend, in a day of AdverÅ¿ity, (to God) by hearty and humble Prayer; And O now they do, as the Prophets man at the Sea-Å¿ide, look again and again, but alas MaÅ¿ter they cry, there is nothing. Prayer is done, concluded, nothing appears; O but as the Prophets
Man looked Å¿eaven times, Å¿o Å¿ays this good man Major Gibbons, look again, as Jonah, I will look again towards his Holy Temple (Å¿ays he to one of the Company) Go up to the top, and Å¿ee what you can eÅ¿py; and at laÅ¿t he makes a Sayl, (viz.) eÅ¿pys a Ship; this puts new life into all their Å¿pirits; they bear up with the VeÅ¿Å¿el, they Man their Boat, they deÅ¿ire, in the manner of periÅ¿hing humble Suppliants, to Board them, which they are Admitted; the VeÅ¿Å¿el proves a French VeÅ¿Å¿el, yea, a French Pyrate; Major Gibbons Petitions him for a little Bread to Å¿uÅ¿tain their lives, who had been Å¿everal days wiÅ¿hing for death, but could not find it in their Extremity; and take the Ship and Cargo. So Å¿weet is life, that all that a man hath will he give for his life; and now behold, God draws forth to theÅ¿e Poor PeriÅ¿hing men his beÅ¿t Wine to the laÅ¿t, nay, turns the Water of Affliction into the Wine of ConÅ¿olation. The Commander of the VeÅ¿Å¿el knows the Major, and replys readily and chearfully, Major Gibbons, not one hair of your head Å¿hall periÅ¿h, nor any of your Ships Company, if it lye in my power either to Å¿upply you, or preÅ¿erve you. O the WiÅ¿dom of God that hath ways we know not of, to Relieve in the greateÅ¿t
Å¿traits, and cauÅ¿e himÅ¿elf to be Å¿een in the Mount. The Commander of this French Pyrat was one that Å¿ome years before, Major Gibbons had Å¿hown Å¿ignal KindneÅ¿s to, when his life was in danger at BoÅ¿ton in New England. Thus the Lord appeared a God, hearing Prayers in Extremitys, which appearances are not to be forgotten in Å¿ucceeding Generations. O that men would praiÅ¿e the Lord for his goodneÅ¿s, and for his wonderful works to the Children of men.

Secondly. About the year 1636. there ariÅ¿ing a Å¿torm and tempeÅ¿t of troubles in the Church of Scotland, five MiniÅ¿ters, eminent for Piety, Learning, and their Honourable Å¿ucceÅ¿s in the MiniÅ¿try, were Å¿o hard born under by a prevailing Party impoÅ¿ing upon their ConÅ¿ciences, that they were forced to Embarque themÅ¿elves for America; three of their names were Mr. LevinÅ¿ton, Mr. Mackleland; and Mr. Blaire, with two more whom my Author could not call to mind.

TheÅ¿e good men Say â¢â¢ d half the Channel over, about 500. Leagues, where they met with great diÅ¿treÅ¿s of weather, which broke off the Rudder of their Ship, and occaÅ¿ioned a deÅ¿perate leak to Å¿pring in her, which expoÅ¿ed them to eminent
danger; but they in this diÅ¿treÅ¿s endeavour to hang on their Rudder again, but often were they fruÅ¿trated in their attempt, to a total deÅ¿pair of effecting it. They alÅ¿o laboured with the like unÅ¿ucceÅ¿sfulneÅ¿s to find out and Å¿top the leak; this poor Ships Crew had laboured alÅ¿o by pumping, to keep the Ship above water, until all their few hands were feeble, and all their hearts faint; Å¿o that as Å¿o many diÅ¿pairing perÅ¿ons of life, they ceaÅ¿e all endeavours, and yield themÅ¿elves to death, expecting every moment to be Entombed in the belly of the devouring deeps; during the time of this their great diÅ¿treÅ¿s, the MiniÅ¿ters kept on their courÅ¿e, as at other times of WorÅ¿hip, (viz) the reading of a Chapter in courÅ¿e, and taking obÅ¿ervations from it, with Prayers and Preaching, which they did by turns; at the criÅ¿is of this deplorable caÅ¿e, it fell to be the Lott of Mr. Mackleland to perform this ExerciÅ¿e, a man AuÅ¿teer in his life, reÅ¿erved in his Å¿peech, and of great Piety, who was often obÅ¿erved to let fall many remarkable Prophetical ExpreÅ¿Å¿ions of future events; the Chapter that at that time came to be read in courÅ¿e by him, was the 3 â¢ of Exodus, which he had read all along (until he came to the 12th.
verÅ¿e.) where he made a full Å¿top; the verÅ¿es run thus.

And MoÅ¿es beÅ¿ought the Lord his God, and Å¿aid, Lord, why doth thy Wrath wax hot againÅ¿t thy people, which thou haÅ¿t brought out of the Land of Egypt with great Power, and a mighty hand? Wherefore Å¿hould the Egyptians Å¿ay, for miÅ¿chief did he bring them out to Å¿lay them in the Mountains, and to conÅ¿ume them from the face of the Earth? Turn from thy Å¿evere Wrath, and repent of this Evil againÅ¿t thy People,âupon the reading of theÅ¿e verÅ¿es over again he declared to them, the CaÅ¿e which MoÅ¿es was here interceeding for, compared with his ExpoÅ¿tulation in the 12 verÅ¿e, did parallel their caÅ¿e, and conÅ¿idering the happy event of that Argument, which MoÅ¿es uÅ¿ed (mentioned in the 14 verÅ¿e, which runs thus:) and the Lord Repented of the Evil which he thought to doe unto his Peopleâhe could not but comfortably hope, that they might have the Å¿ame Effect: Nay he goes further, and his Spirit raiÅ¿ed into a peremptory prediction, that he durÅ¿t aÅ¿Å¿ure them from his great Lord and MaÅ¿ter, that not one hair of their heads Å¿hould fall to the ground; after this he went to Prayer, urging God with the
Å¿ame Argument, and then roÅ¿e up comfortably aÅ¿Å¿uring his Å¿tedfaÅ¿tneÅ¿s in believing the Å¿ame; he adviÅ¿es the Sea-men and the Company in the Ship to refreÅ¿h themÅ¿elves by taking Å¿ome meat, the long faÅ¿ting and hard labour having much infeebled them. Then he encouraged them to make another Attempt to faÅ¿ten the Rudder, without which they could not poÅ¿Å¿ible make towards any point for Å¿hore. He after adviÅ¿ed them to clear the Å¿hip, as well as they could, from water by pumping, which they did happily Effect, the Leak being Å¿topt providentially of it Å¿elfâwhether it was Å¿ome noak of a plank Å¿tarted by the deÅ¿treÅ¿s of weather which occaÅ¿ioned the Leak, and by the Å¿urges of the Sea, clapt into the place again, or what it was elÅ¿e could not be known. But however this lookes like life from the dead to theÅ¿e poor men, who had received but a little before a Å¿entence of Death in themÅ¿elves, that they might truÅ¿t in him who raiÅ¿eth the Dead. Soon after this, God who had heard in Heaven great Tears and Prayers, Commands the Wind Tack about to the WeÅ¿t, and to blow Å¿o Å¿trong a gale that they were forced to bear up before it, and it continued Å¿o
long, that it brought them back to the North of Ireland, where they continued Å¿ome time; although but Å¿hort, they were very inÅ¿trumental in the Converting of many Å¿ouls, which Å¿eed-plot remains to this day; and Å¿oon after they paÅ¿Å¿ed into Scotland. This Relation was given by Å¿everal MiniÅ¿ters of the North of Ireland: alÅ¿o the Reader may take notice, the Author of that Book called the Fullfilling of the Scriptures, pag. 487. mentions this remarkable Providence, though not Å¿o largely, with theÅ¿e two additional, but very conÅ¿iderable circumÅ¿tances; firÅ¿t, That a poor Sea-man was made the inÅ¿trument to preÅ¿erve the Å¿ame VeÅ¿Å¿el, by faÅ¿tening the Rudder, whoÅ¿e company they had all Å¿hun'd, others having given it over. Secondly, Several PaÅ¿Å¿engers being Aboard, who Å¿hipt themÅ¿elves for America, upon only external accounts, expecting a fat Å¿oyle, and outward advantage in that place, and not as the others upon the account of ConÅ¿cience, to enjoy the purity of Ordinances; they did all dye upon the Sea Å¿ave one, being five in number. And who is Å¿o blind, as cannot Å¿ee here the out Å¿tretched Arm of an Omnipotent God, commanding deliverance for his poor diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed, perÅ¿ecuted,
praying, believing Servants, and alÅ¿o for all them that Sayled with them? O who would not Pray at Sea, and truÅ¿t in him who raiÅ¿es the dead in the Å¿addeÅ¿t of their Extremities and diÅ¿treÅ¿s! and Å¿peaks forth much of the power and goodneÅ¿s of God, calling upon all to truÅ¿t in him, let the dangers and Å¿traits be never Å¿o great.

4. A Å¿mall VeÅ¿Å¿el, about 45 Tun, the MaÅ¿ters name Phillip Hangare, coming upon the CoaÅ¿t of New-England, they Å¿uddenly Å¿prang a leak, and Å¿o foundred: There were in this poor miÅ¿carrying VeÅ¿Å¿el 18 Sea-men and PaÅ¿Å¿engers; 12 of the men got into the Long-boat, and as that was Å¿uddenly brought to their minds in this Å¿urpriÅ¿e, they threw into their Boat alÅ¿o Å¿ome Å¿mall matters of ProviÅ¿ions, but they were wholly without fire: TheÅ¿e 12 men at that time of the year about Michaelmas, (and as Paul Å¿aid in his Voyage, Sayling was become dangerous) Sayled five hundred Leagues, and were to a Miracle preÅ¿erved all that time in this Å¿mall Boat, five weeks; but it pleaÅ¿ed the Lord, who appears in our Å¿traits moÅ¿t, to Å¿end them
great relief, by cauÅ¿ing Å¿ome flying FiÅ¿h to fall into the Boat, which they eat raw, and were unto them more acceptable than the greateÅ¿t rarities and dainties at another time; God's Providence now proving the Caterer, they catch'd a Shark, and that Ravenous FiÅ¿h that uÅ¿es to prey upon men, now becomes a prey to theÅ¿e poor diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed Creatures; but they were glad of food in the want of fire, and have an heat in their Stomacks, to eat that raw, and digeÅ¿t at this time what would have made them Å¿ick at other times; but alas, another want they had, was drink as well as fire, but they were forced to open the belly of this Shark, and Å¿uck his blood for drink; at laÅ¿t, that God who hath a deÅ¿ire to the work of his own hands, gives them hopes to releaÅ¿e them out of this inÅ¿upportable miÅ¿ery, by letting them come to a diÅ¿covery of Land in the WeÅ¿t-Indies; but alas, they were Å¿o weak, that when they came aÅ¿hore, one or two of them dyed; but moÅ¿t of them lived to declare the works of the Lord. This the Author had from one of the 12 that were thus miraculouÅ¿ly preÅ¿erved, but Å¿ince caÅ¿t away at Sea.

5. Captain Jonas Clark, of New-England, going for Virginia, the VeÅ¿Å¿el was CaÅ¿t away in a Å¿trange amazing manner, about two hours before day, among the Indians where the Ship-wrackt men lay aÅ¿hore in great fear; but three days after they thought to get their Å¿hip off again; to which end the MaÅ¿ter, with Å¿ome others, went into the boat, they came threeÅ¿core Fathom from the Å¿hore, where there aroÅ¿e a great Sea, and broke in upon them; but the Å¿econd Sea came and turned the boat up; four men under water, all were drowned, but Captain Clark, who was kept under water by one of the men, until his breath was gone, but then God appeared, and Å¿et him at liberty from him in a moÅ¿t Miraculous way, and inabled him to Å¿wim to the Å¿hore; they that were alive now, were in great Å¿traits and perplexities, not knowing what to do, but yet Å¿ome of their eyes were up to God; at laÅ¿t they UnanimouÅ¿ly reÅ¿olve to Travel, and when they had Travelled one night, and part of a day, meeting with many Swamps and thick places, Å¿o that all hope failed them of going along, Å¿o they Å¿tood Å¿till as (wayfaring men) aÅ¿toniÅ¿h'd, not knowing what courÅ¿e to take; and though before they were afraid of any
Indians, now they were glad to pray to the Lord for the Å¿ight of an Indian, which in this extremity and perplexity, within half an hour the Lord was pleaÅ¿ed to grant: The Indian was all alone, which was obÅ¿ervable alÅ¿o; when they got to him, they asked the way to the EngliÅ¿h, and they did perÅ¿wade him by entreaty to go along with them, but within one hours time, he carryed them to a Town of the Indians, which did Å¿adly fright and amaze them; but they Å¿till looked up to the Lord to help and Å¿ave them; and at laÅ¿t they got to the EngliÅ¿h, and Å¿o were preÅ¿erved.
This Relation the Author had from Captain Clarks own hand, a perÅ¿on of known GodlineÅ¿s and Integrity.

6. The laÅ¿t Providence called to mind a Å¿trange and Å¿tupendious paÅ¿Å¿age of a Godly Gentlewoman, who in the firÅ¿t breaking forth of the Rebellion in Ireland, was forced to fly for her life, with Å¿ome other perÅ¿ons in her Company; eÅ¿pecially three Children, one of them upon her BreaÅ¿t: But alas, theÅ¿e poor trembling Travellers had not gone long before they were Å¿triped Naked by the IriÅ¿h, who to admiration Å¿pared their lives; but paÅ¿Å¿ing
on to the foot of a River, others met them and would have caÅ¿t them into the River but this Godly Woman not being diÅ¿may'd, ask'd a little liberty to Pray, and as Å¿he lay on frozen ground Naked, Å¿he got a little reÅ¿olution not to go on her own feet to Å¿o unjuÅ¿t a death; upon which having call'd her, upon her reÅ¿olution, they drag'd her by the heels along the ground, with the reÅ¿t of the Company; Å¿he turns upon them, and on her knees Å¿ays, You Å¿hould I am Å¿ure be ChriÅ¿tians, and men I Å¿ee you are; in taking away our miÅ¿erable lives you do us a pleaÅ¿ure; but know, as we never wrong'd you, nor yours, you muÅ¿t dye alÅ¿o your Å¿elves, and one day give an account of this Cruelty to the Judge of Heaven and Earth. Suddenly upon which, an IriÅ¿h PrieÅ¿t Å¿ays, Let us not take their lives, but we will put them in this IÅ¿land of the Lake; a Boat being at the River, all the eight Naked, and without Meat, are turn'd into that IÅ¿land, where after four days Å¿taying, Å¿ome of the Company dy'd with Hunger and Cold, but not this Woman, nor any of her Children; a day after, the two Boys found the Hyde of a BeaÅ¿t which had been kill'd at the root of a Tree, which they and the Mother endeavoured to caÅ¿t over them; then
â¢ ying upon the Snow, the next day a little â¢ oat goes by, to whom Å¿he calls for God's â¢ ake to take her out, but they refus'd, â¢ eing IriÅ¿h; Å¿he deÅ¿ir'd a little Bread, but â¢ hey Å¿aid they had none; Å¿he begs a Coal â¢ f Fire, which Å¿he obtain'd, for they had â¢ ome fewel in the Boat, and thus with â¢ ome fallen Chips, made a fire; and the â¢ oys taking a piece of the Hyde, lay'd it â¢ pon the Coals, and began to gnaw the â¢ eather; but alas, without an extraordi
â¢ ary Divine Å¿upport, what could this do? Thus they lived ten days without any vi
â¢ ble Å¿upplies, and that good Woman pro
â¢ eÅ¿t it was by Faith and Joy in God Å¿he â¢ iv'd; nor had Å¿he any Bread but Ice and â¢ now, nor any Drink but Water, but Å¿he â¢ hought God put more Å¿ubÅ¿tance in it, and â¢ ound it as it were clammy. The next â¢ ay a Boat carryed her out to the Å¿ide of â¢ he Band-water, where yet Å¿he had been â¢ oÅ¿t, but that Å¿he could not Å¿uffer to Å¿ee her Children dye in her Å¿ight; and therefore ãâã though the two Boys were young, and Å¿o â¢ tarv'd, that they had no Å¿trength) Å¿he â¢ reÅ¿Å¿ed them to go out of her Å¿ight, under â¢ retence of Å¿eeking Å¿ome fire; the poor Children had not gone far until they Å¿aw â¢ wo or 3 great Dogs eating a man who had â¢ een kill'd; the Children were not afraid
of the Dogs, (who needed not fear any thing but to live in Å¿uch a Condition) and one of them came running, and leaped upon one of the Children, without doing him the leaÅ¿t hurt, and would run a little before, and then tarry until the Children come up, and Å¿o led them on where an HouÅ¿e whence Smoke appeared, which was an IriÅ¿h mans, Protected by the EngliÅ¿h in Antrum, by which means they were marvellouÅ¿ly pleaÅ¿ed, and the Mother Å¿ent for, and Å¿uccour'd by a party from Antrum. Although this Providence be not a Sea-deliverance, yet it is a remarkable preÅ¿ervation from danger by Water, and Hunger at Land.

7. In the firÅ¿t Å¿etling of the Bohemi â¢
IÅ¿lands off the Cape of Florida, about the year 1642. there were at that preÅ¿ent great troubles in the Burmoudas, one Captaine Sale who had been Governour the year before, comes for London, and here informing Å¿ome of his Acquaintance and PerÅ¿ons of Worth and EÅ¿tate, how things then Å¿tood, they undertake fo â¢ him, and got him a Ship, and all thing â¢ neceÅ¿Å¿ary for the diÅ¿covery of theÅ¿e IÅ¿land â¢ which he had inform'd them of, Å¿ â¢ they proceeded to Burmoudas, whe â¢â¢ they took in Å¿everal PaÅ¿Å¿engers, Captai â¢â¢
Sale being Cheif, and Captain Lane and his Family which came from London with him as his AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tant in the management of the DeÅ¿igne, Å¿o they in purÅ¿ute of the Voyage, came to an IÅ¿land call'd Cicatra,
â¢ he lay down in the Platts, where they could not at preÅ¿ent find an Harbour. So they Å¿ent out their Shallop upon a diÅ¿covery, which upon Return inform'd them of a better place to Ride in.âBut Å¿ending out the Shallop again upon a diÅ¿covery, before Å¿he Return'd, there aroÅ¿e a dreadful Storm that carried her immediately upon the Rocks, and Å¿tav'd her, with very much difficulty moÅ¿t of the People were Å¿av'd, and Å¿ome ProviÅ¿ions. Then were they Reduc'd to very great Å¿traits formidable to fleÅ¿h and blood, a Barren IÅ¿land, no inhabitants, no likelyhood of Releif, little ProviÅ¿ions left; in this great Å¿trait moÅ¿t of them reÅ¿olv'd to travel up to the weÅ¿ter end of the IÅ¿land and there to abide. (Captaine Lane and his Family, and his Son who was his Leiutenant) they ReÅ¿olv'd to Å¿eek for Å¿ome kind of ProviÅ¿ions, and Å¿o Å¿tay'd on the IÅ¿land. But Captaine Sale and one Mr. Bounly who had been MaÅ¿ter of the Ship, and Å¿ome other Sea-men, and one Mr. Shadwel;
ã1 page duplicateã
ã1 page duplicateã
in all eight, ReÅ¿olv'd to go to Virginia, and took what ProviÅ¿ions they could get, which was one Shark; but before they made to the Land they were in very great wants; For from this IÅ¿land from whence they departed to Virginia, was three hundred Leagues: in their now great Extreamity, Providence car'd for them, Å¿o that they got another Shark, and were glad to eat him Raw. They were a 11 days going to Virginia, and the Boat a very little one, that they could Å¿carcely Steer in her for fear of danger. Yet the Lord in this deep DiÅ¿treÅ¿s, made his Arm bare for their Salvation, and brought them Å¿afe to a place call'd NuÅ¿e mum; to one Mr. Richard Brunkets HouÅ¿e, where they were curtiouÅ¿ly Entertain'd; and after the Relation upon what account they were put to theÅ¿e HardÅ¿hips and NeceÅ¿Å¿ities, Captain Sale had a VeÅ¿Å¿el provided laden with neceÅ¿Å¿aries, to go for Cicatra, to Relieve thoÅ¿e they had left there in Å¿uch DiÅ¿treÅ¿s, and they arriv'd there. And O now what Comfort muÅ¿t this be, after Å¿uch long wiÅ¿hing and gradual Dying, to Å¿ee that there was now Hopes of Life brought to them; but Å¿everal of them were Å¿tarv'd to Death before their
Arrival. Captain Lane is now Å¿ent to fetch Å¿ome ProviÅ¿ions who had been in unÅ¿peakable Extreamity. He came down in a little Boat, his Son alÅ¿o the Lieutenant and two Servants, but when they had gotten in their ProviÅ¿ion, and going home with hopes of a new Life; Behold, the Å¿tupendious providence of God, all of a Å¿udden Death creeps in and ArreÅ¿ts them. For in a narrow place where the Tyde runs Å¿wiftly, the Boat is Å¿unk, all are drowned but one man, who carried the deÅ¿olate Widdow the Å¿ad Tydings â¢ what an unwelcome MeÅ¿Å¿enger this was you may eaÅ¿ily conjecture; about three months after arrived a VeÅ¿Å¿el to them (the maÅ¿ter of her my Author,) and Å¿o Mrs. Lane, her Son and Daughter, Maid Servant and Man Servant, where all brought up about forty miles, where they were entertain'd by my Author for Å¿ix weeks, and gave an account of Å¿ome notable paÅ¿Å¿ages of Gods Providence in preÅ¿erving them. Worthy never to be forgotten! Her Husband and the men went out to Å¿ee what they could get for ãâã every Day, and they had for the moÅ¿t part juÅ¿t for the Day, and Å¿he told my Author that Å¿he as a tender hearted Mother would lay Å¿omething
by for her younger Children; but Å¿he obÅ¿erv'd that the next Day they never got any thing.

And thus Providence train'd them up in the School of Faith; but further Å¿he gave an account of one Remarkable thing, In the laÅ¿t day of the week, upon a time it proved a very Å¿tormy Day, and they being abroad a hunting for Å¿ome Å¿upport, could get nothing. The Husband and Son comes home very much troubled, and the men that were gon into the Woods they could get nothing; and they being very much troubled, one took up a ReÅ¿olution not to come home, knowing their Captain would not Å¿uffer them to go and hunt on the Lords Day; on the other hand they thought he would wounder what was become of them, and fear leÅ¿t evil had befallen them; Å¿o they alter their ReÅ¿olution to come home, but empty of any Reliefe; this very Evening before the Sabbath in this perplexety of thoughts, there flys over their Heads three gray GeeÅ¿e; a wonder it was for Å¿uch GeeÅ¿e that were never Å¿een before nor after. O Å¿ays Å¿he to her Husband, that we had Å¿ome of them againÅ¿t to morrow! obÅ¿erving they lighted in a Bottome, Å¿he acquaints her
Husband, he Å¿ays they have no Å¿hot left. O Å¿ays Å¿he, here is a Porrenger, melt it or cut it into peices, which he did for expedition, and charged his Peice, and at the firÅ¿t Å¿hot kill'd them all,âTheÅ¿e things, and many more my Author had from her own Mouth, after her marvellous PreÅ¿ervation. O that men would PraiÅ¿e the Lord, for his wonderful Works to the Children of Men.

8. We have a very wonderful Deliverance recorded, an honeÅ¿t poor man in Maulden in EÅ¿Å¿ex, one Gregory Crow, who with his man and boy, was in his Boat going to fetch Fullers-Earth; but by the way meeting with a Stom his Boat was driven upon a banck of Å¿and, and there Å¿unk; The men were glad to hang upon the MaÅ¿t, but poor Crow Å¿eeing his New-TeÅ¿tament in the water, which he prized highly, caught it up, and took it into his BoÅ¿om; the tyde being gone, they were left upon the Å¿and, at leaÅ¿t ten miles from land; now in this great DiÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e they made their Prayers to the Lord, that he would Å¿end Å¿ome means of Deliverance, For now within half an hour it would be flood, but in this little time before Flood, they found a CheÅ¿t wherein was five pounds Å¿ix Shillings
eight pence, but honeÅ¿t Crow caÅ¿t it into the Sea again Å¿aying, If the Lord will pleaÅ¿e to Å¿ave our lives he will provide us a little food; and Å¿o they went again up the MaÅ¿t, where they to Admiration hung by the Arms and Leggs for ten hours together, only the Boy was Å¿o weary, and beaten with the Waves that he fell off, and was drowned; now their fears encreaÅ¿e upon them, and they know not what to do. But Crow adviÅ¿es his man to cut down the MaÅ¿t and when the F â¢ ood comes again, to fit upon it, and Å¿o, Å¿ayes he, it may pleaÅ¿e God to drive us to Å¿ome Ship; this Councel was taken, they commit themÅ¿elves to God upon this MaÅ¿t, and thus continu'd TueÅ¿day Night, WedneÅ¿day, and WedneÅ¿day Night; in which time the man was Å¿o tir'd out with Hunger, Watching, and Cold, that he dyed; now was Crow left alone in this Å¿ad and deplorable Condition, who pray'd now the more earneÅ¿tly for Å¿ome Succor and Relief, but durÅ¿t not Sleep, leÅ¿t the Sea Å¿hould beat him off the MaÅ¿t; and when this diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿'d miÅ¿erable object was almoÅ¿t Å¿pent, his fleÅ¿h Å¿odden with Sea water, and his eyes almoÅ¿t cloÅ¿ed up with the Salt, now in his Extremity the Lord makes it his opportunity, and Å¿ â¢â¢ eps in by his Providence, perÅ¿ents a Ship going
for Antwerp: (obÅ¿erve here the Finger of God:) The Wind not being favourable was driven out of the way, and eÅ¿pying Å¿omething a far off in the Sea, but Å¿uppoÅ¿eing it to be Å¿ome FiÅ¿her-boy Å¿teer'd from it. Crow Å¿eeing this, held up his Cap and Å¿haked it over his head, whereby at length they were mov'd to go to him, and Å¿o they took him in; when he came into the Ship, being half dead, careful of his New TeÅ¿tament, he pluckt it out of his BoÅ¿ome and gave it to Å¿ome to dry. They in the Ship were careful of him, and with great difficulty recover'd him, and carryed him with them to Antwerp, where the fame of his being miraculouÅ¿ly deliver'd, drew many to Å¿ee him, and relieve him with neceÅ¿Å¿aries. Fox's Book of Martyrs.

9. A Ship of Holland being driven againÅ¿t her will, came to a Place call'd Zembla, where the Pole is elevated Seventy Six degrees; they among many delays, and great dangers, Å¿carce reach'd the Aurange IÅ¿lands; for now they were Å¿et faÅ¿t in a ConÅ¿olidated body of continu'd Ice, which threatn'd them every moment; at laÅ¿t being reduc'd to their ultimate hope, they reÅ¿olve to return the Å¿ame way they came, but now they find the
Ship quite frozen up, not far from Å¿hore, and now they think they Å¿hould winter in Zembla and waite for a better SeaÅ¿on, wherefore taking out Boards and Plancks, they built for themÅ¿elves, and their Stuffe, a poor Å¿helter, and by a good Providence, the Tide had thrown up a good quantity of Timber, they not knowing from whence it came, it proved a great advantage to them during their abode; here they had continual fights with Bears, which Å¿ometimes were driven away with making great out-crys, other whiles with Shot â¢ they found their fleÅ¿h unwholeÅ¿ome for food. (For in this place the Maritine wild BeaÅ¿ts, are the food to the wild BeaÅ¿ts of the land) the fat of the Bears they made uÅ¿e of to burn for lights in the night; theÅ¿e poor creatures were at laÅ¿t, after all other Humane Benefits, left by the Sun, in this Barren Country, and left amongÅ¿t none but wild BeaÅ¿ts: The vaÅ¿t Mountains of Snow, with great difficulty they remove, leÅ¿t the Habitation Å¿hould be overwhelm'd, and if at any time they went forth, their jawes were Å¿o benum'd they could Å¿carce recover their former heat; now the Bears in the dark, being dull of fight did not venture out to diÅ¿turbe them, but multitudes of Foxes, which
they took in Traps, and made of them both Victuals and Rayment; and yet after all theÅ¿e dangers and difficultys God preÅ¿erved them, though indeed Å¿ome of them dyed, they were 12 of them: The chief of them was one Jacob Hamskerk, who returned afterwards to AmÅ¿terdam. Gro
â¢ ius in his Annalls.

10. In the year 1616 a flemming named Pickman, well known in England and Holland, for the art he had in getting out of the Sea, the great Guns of that SpaniÅ¿h Fleet, that was forced upon the CoaÅ¿t of Ireland and Scotland, in the year 1588. coming from Dronthem in Norway, laden with Boards, was overtaken by a Calm, during which, the current of the Sea carryed him on a Rock or a little IÅ¿land towards the extremity of Scotland, where he was in Å¿ome danger of being caÅ¿t away; to avoide a wrack, he commanded Å¿ome of his men to go into the Å¿hallop, and to tow off the Ship: theÅ¿e having done Å¿o, would needs go upon a certain Rock to Å¿eek for eggs, but as Å¿oon as they were got up into it, they eÅ¿py'd a man, whence they imagine there were others lay there about, and that he had made an EÅ¿cape thither to avoid Å¿ome Pirats which might Surprize their Ship, Å¿o that they made all
the haÅ¿t they could to the Shallop, and return'd to the Ship; but the Calme continuing, and the current of the Sea driving the VeÅ¿Å¿el againÅ¿t the IÅ¿land, they were forc'd to get into the Long-boat and Tow her off again; the man they Å¿aw before, was in the mean time come to the brink of the IÅ¿land, and made Å¿ignes to them with his hands, entreating them to come nearer; and falling on his Knees, and joyning his Hands together, he beg'd Relief from them; at laÅ¿t coming near the IÅ¿land, they Å¿aw Å¿omething more like a GhoÅ¿t than a living PerÅ¿on, a body Å¿tark Naked, black, hairy, of a meager and deform'd Countenance, hollow and diÅ¿torted Eyes, which raiÅ¿ed Å¿uch CompaÅ¿Å¿ion in them, that they proffer'd to take him into their Boat; at laÅ¿t with Å¿ome difficulty they took him in; they found upon the IÅ¿land no GraÅ¿s nor Trees, nothing for Food, nor any Å¿helter, but the ruins of a boat, wherewith he had made himÅ¿elf an Hut, under which he might be cover'd from Rain and injuries of the Weather; when they came to ask him who he was, and how he came into that un-inhabited place, he reply'd to them he was an EngliÅ¿h Man, and that a year before he was to go from England
to Dublin in Ireland in the PaÅ¿Å¿age-Boat, and that they were taken by a French-Pyrate, who by a Storm that immediately aroÅ¿e, was forc'd to let go the PaÅ¿Å¿age-Boat, left us to the mercy of the Waves, which carryed us between Ireland and Scotland, into the main Sea, expecting to be caÅ¿t away every minute, as at laÅ¿t we were: For the Bark being Å¿plit againÅ¿t the Rock, where you took me in, I eÅ¿caped with one of my Comrades into the IÅ¿land, in a more wretched condition than if Å¿wallow'd up by the Sea; who then had been deliver'd out of the Extremities we were in for want of meat and drink; of Å¿ome of the boards of our Boat we made the Hutt you Å¿aw, and we took Å¿ome Seamews which we Å¿et a drying in the Wind and Sun, and Å¿o eat them raw; we found alÅ¿o in the crevices of the Rock, by the Sea-Å¿ide, Å¿ome Eggs: Thus were we kept from Å¿tarving; but what we thought moÅ¿t inÅ¿upportable, was ThirÅ¿t; for there was no Water, but what fell from Heaven; we liv'd thus Å¿ix weeks, comforting one another, and finding Å¿ome eaÅ¿e in our common misfortune, till that being left alone, it began to grow inÅ¿upportable to me; for one day, awaking in the morning, and miÅ¿Å¿ing my Comrade, I fell into
Å¿uch a DeÅ¿pair, that I had Å¿ome though â¢ of caÅ¿ting my Å¿elf head-long, and Å¿o put a final period to that Affliction, whereof I had but endur'd the one half while I had a Friend Å¿uffering with me: I know not what became of him, but I am of that opinion that he fell into the Sea, Å¿eeking for Eggs; I left with him my Knife, with which we kill'd the Sea-Doggs, and the Mews, upon which we lived; Å¿o I was forc'd to get out of my Hut a great Nail, which I made a Å¿hift to Å¿harpen upon the Rock, that it Å¿erv'd me for a Knife: I was alÅ¿o forc'd to lade a little Å¿tick, with a little Sea-dogg fat, and put it out of a crevice of my Hut, and Å¿o got Å¿ome Mews to keep me from Å¿tarving: I liv'd in this condition and Å¿olitude Eleven Months, and was reÅ¿olv'd to end my days in it, when God Å¿ent you to deliver me out of the greateÅ¿t miÅ¿ery that ever man was in, and this Sea-man after this miÅ¿ery and miraculous preÅ¿ervation, liv'd to return to England. AmbaÅ¿adors Travels.

div.head: A Remarkable Providence of God in wonderfully preÅ¿erving of Eleven or Thirteen poor diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed mens lives.
div.p:
11. In the year 68. a Ketch Sailed from Salom in New-England for the Barbadoes;
and when they came into the Latitude of 35. it began to look like foul weather, Å¿o they took in their Top-Å¿ail, and becauÅ¿e it was towards night, they Å¿truck down the Main Å¿ail, and Rafed it; and all this time there was but a little wind (which was remarkable, if the enÅ¿uing Å¿tory be obÅ¿erv'd) but Å¿till it looked like bad weather; Å¿o they Å¿ent up one to Tallow tho MaÅ¿t, and made no great haÅ¿t to Å¿et Sayll; the man at the Top thinks he Å¿ees Å¿ome black thing float upon the Sea, and looking upon it very fixtly, he conceives it to be a Boat, and Å¿o calls to the men below, Å¿o they haÅ¿ten'd to hoiÅ¿e Sayl and make towards it; and when they came to them, there was a Long-boat with a 11 or 13 men, (my Author could not abÅ¿olutely remember the juÅ¿t number) which poor diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed Creatures, had been bound for Virginia; and the Å¿hip in which they were, prov'd very Leaky, and Å¿o exceedingly encreas'd, that in a very little time, Å¿he was ready to Å¿ink; Å¿o all hands haÅ¿ten'd to get out the boat, but the MaÅ¿ter Å¿tept into the Cabbin to fetch a CompaÅ¿s, and took Å¿ome Canvas, a Sayl-needle and twine which he thought might be uÅ¿eful to them in their Need and Extremity, but while â¢ his poor induÅ¿trious man was endeavouring
to be uÅ¿eful to Å¿ome other mens lives, he was in danger to loÅ¿e his own; for the boat was put off, and the Å¿hip Å¿inking, Å¿o he crys to them in this diÅ¿treÅ¿s, if they would leave him, and let him there PeriÅ¿h; Å¿o they came back, and took him in; they had in their boat a CapÅ¿tone-bar, which they made uÅ¿e of for a MaÅ¿t, and the piece of Canvas for a Sayl, and Å¿o Sayled afore the wind, and had no kind of Food; and now comes dreadful and inexpreÅ¿Å¿ible diÅ¿treÅ¿s upon them, making them wiÅ¿h for death it Å¿elf to give them a deliverance, now all hopes of Relief fail'd them; thus they continu'd five days, Å¿ome grew Lame, others Feeble, and all much diÅ¿hearten'd by deÅ¿pair of Life; and now upon the 6th. day, they had concluded to caÅ¿t Lotts for their lives, who Å¿hould dye to preÅ¿erve others; and they put their ReÅ¿olution into Execution, and that poor Creature, upon whom the Lott fell, begs for time; but alas, what will a Reprieve be in this caÅ¿e, where there is no hope of Relief; but O what difficult work is it to dye? what a Å¿trait was here? Live he could not, and Dye he could not; well, a little time is defer'd, and behold a wonder-working God appears now for him, and for them all; before night, they eÅ¿py'd
this Ketch, which rais'd them all to Admiration; but they had fears in this diÅ¿treÅ¿s, that the Ketch did not Å¿ee them; but when they perceiv'd the Ketch made to them, O what a new life did it put into theÅ¿e dying men; Å¿o they all got Å¿afe Aboard: And Å¿ee here the goodneÅ¿s of God: In one hour after there aroÅ¿e a moÅ¿t dreadful Storm which continu'd for forty hours, and all of them Å¿afely Arriv'd at Barbadoes.
The MaÅ¿ters name of the Ketch was Thomas Woodberry of Salom. This the Author had from a very known perÅ¿on of Integrity and GodlineÅ¿s, now living at Salom.

12. In the year 1606. in the Wars betwixt the Netherlands and the Spaniards, upon the SpaniÅ¿h Ocean, fell out this obÅ¿ervable and remarkable action, taken notice of by Grotius, in his Annals of the Low-Country Wars. Admiral Hauteen being Å¿ent to intercept the SpaniÅ¿h Fleet, coming from America and the Indies, he had with him four and twenty VeÅ¿Å¿els; but of theÅ¿e, Å¿ix were beaten back by TempeÅ¿ts; Å¿oon after FraÅ¿ciardo, with eight great Gallions, having a proÅ¿perous Gale, fell upon them unprovided,
