It put him into Å¿uch a profound conÅ¿ternation, that he reÅ¿olved to find out Å¿ome way to tender his reÅ¿pects to this mighty Prince, and no way could he find Å¿o convenient, as to tell the Relator, that if he could find but a paÅ¿Å¿age, he would let him go to England, to tell his MajeÅ¿ty of the great favour and reÅ¿pect he had for him. This did not a little rejoyce our EngliÅ¿h-man. Withall the King told him, that he would Å¿end him a PreÅ¿ent, which Å¿hould be two Cabareets or Goats, which they do value at a very high rate; the King having not above 16 or 18. He tells the King, that the King of England had many thouÅ¿ands of his Subjects that were under the degree of Gentlemen, which had a thouÅ¿and of Sheep a piece; the fleÅ¿h of which, they valu'd at a very much higher rate than
Goats. Though our EngliÅ¿h-man lived very handÅ¿omely with this E-fn-man-cha, King of the Ca-la-nanch, yet his deÅ¿ires and his hopes were Å¿till for his Native Country: at length he obtain'd a promiÅ¿e from his King, that the firÅ¿t EngliÅ¿h Å¿hip that came into that Road, Å¿hould have liberty to ReleaÅ¿e or PurchaÅ¿e him; this very much rejoyced his heart: now he thought every day a year, till he could hear of, or Å¿ee Å¿ome EngliÅ¿h Å¿hip arrived. Many times when he was alone, his heart would be oppreÅ¿t with Å¿ighs and Å¿obbings, when ke thought of his Relations, and the comfortable Å¿ociety that they had together; that it Å¿hould be his Å¿ad lot to be captivated amongÅ¿t barbarous Infidels. Oftentimes did he walk down to the Sea-Å¿ide, Å¿ometimes with hopes, Å¿ometimes with fear, earneÅ¿tly expecting the wind of Gods providence to blow in Å¿ome EngliÅ¿h Ship thither: his often recourÅ¿e to the Sea-Å¿ide was diÅ¿cerned by one Ja-ga, a Wizard, and the chiefeÅ¿t in three or four Kingdoms there-abouts; they are perÅ¿ons that the Natives give very much credit to, and on any difficult occaÅ¿ion, run to them for Å¿atisfaction. The famous Delphean Oracle was never had in greater adoration, than the prophetical
Speeches of theÅ¿e MoriÅ¿h Wizards. Though they have infinite numbers of them in every place, yet this Ja-ga had the moÅ¿t renown amongÅ¿t them; and one day he comes to him, and very kindly ask'd him, Why he Å¿o very often frequented that place? he told him, To Å¿ee if he could diÅ¿cover any EngliÅ¿h VeÅ¿Å¿el to come in there: but he being not acquainted with his Great fame, Askt him When he did believe there would one come in? not that he was willing to give credit to any of their Divinations, but Å¿uppoÅ¿ing that he thereby Å¿hould pleaÅ¿e him and anÅ¿wer his expectation. Ja-ga immediately told him, That the Fifteenth day after an EngliÅ¿h Ship Å¿hould come into the Road. Then he askt him, Whether that Ship Å¿hould carry him away. To this he anÅ¿wer'd doubtfully, but told him, That he Å¿hould be offer'd to the MaÅ¿ter of the Å¿hip, and if they could not agree, but that he Å¿hould come to Shore again, he Å¿hould not be Sold, and that in a very Å¿hort time after he Å¿hould dye for Grief. TheÅ¿e Fifteen days Å¿eem'd very long and tedious; many a look did he caÅ¿t on the Sea with an Aking heart: The Fourteenth day he went to the higheÅ¿t Hill ãâã , but to no purpoÅ¿e, for he could diÅ¿cover no
Ship: next Morning he went again two or three times, but Å¿aw none: about two or three hours after came running into E-fn-man-cha, Å¿ome of the Moores, and told him there was a Canoe coming, Å¿o they called our Ships; at which our EngliÅ¿h-man heartily rejoyc'd, hoping then to be releaÅ¿t forthwith, yet durÅ¿t not Å¿hew his joy for fear of puniÅ¿hment or of death; for though he lived better now than with his firÅ¿t MaÅ¿ter, yet his Å¿ervice was far worÅ¿e than the Slaves in Turkey, and their Diet worÅ¿e than Dogs-meat; therefore had he cauÅ¿e enough of inward Joy; the Ship came immediately in, and he highs away preÅ¿ently to Ja-ga, to know if it were an EngliÅ¿h Ship, who reÅ¿olved him that it was; it happened to be the St. Maloes Merchant, Captain Royden Commander, who haÅ¿ten'd to diÅ¿patch his BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s, took in his Negroes, and was ready to Å¿ail, and our EngliÅ¿h-man heard never a word what Å¿hould become of him, the King never offering to Å¿ell him; this put him on a reÅ¿olution to endeavour to make an eÅ¿cape, and to that end had prepared a piece of Timber which he had drawn near the water-Å¿ide, on which he intended to paddle to the Ship, which then lay about a League from the Shore. JuÅ¿t
by the Sea-Å¿ide; as he was about to launch his little floating Stick, he eÅ¿pied a Great Aligator, which will devour a Man at a Mouthful; this made him alter his ReÅ¿olution, and reÅ¿olve rather to live with Inhumane Infidels, than to throw himÅ¿elf into Å¿o imminent a danger, which would have been little leÅ¿s than Å¿elf-murther. But the next day, which I may call a day of Jubilee, Almighty God opened the heart of the King to let the poor EngliÅ¿h Man go: he Å¿ent him in a Canoe, placed between a Negroe's Legs, with Å¿ome others to Guide this Å¿mall VeÅ¿Å¿el, for fear he Å¿hould leap over board and Å¿wim to the Ship. At a diÅ¿tance from the Ship he hail'd her in the EngliÅ¿h Tongue, which was no Å¿mall cauÅ¿e of admi â¢ ation to thoÅ¿e on Board to hear an EngliÅ¿h Tongue out of their Canoes: The Negroes gave him leave to Å¿tand up and Å¿hew himÅ¿elf to the Captain, to whom he gave an Account how four were left there, and only he preÅ¿erv'd. It was a pretty while before they could Å¿trike a B â¢ rgain, though the Captain was reÅ¿olv'd not to leave him behind. Several times the Negroes padled away with their Canoe, reÅ¿olving not to part with him; but what with his entreaties and promiÅ¿es, he perÅ¿waded them
to the Ship again, and they deliver'd him on board for Forty five Copper Bars and Iron Bars; each Copper bar being about the bigneÅ¿s of a Youths little finger, the Iron bars a little bigger. Now were his joys compleated, he thought himÅ¿elf, as it were, caught up into the Third Heavens; he could hardly perÅ¿wade himÅ¿elf but it was a Dream or ViÅ¿ion, and that he did not really Å¿ee EngliÅ¿h faces, or embrace EngliÅ¿h bodies. It was Å¿ome time before he could throw himÅ¿elf at the Captains feet, and acknwledge his infinite cauÅ¿e of joy in himÅ¿elf, and thankfulneÅ¿s to him for his deliverance from Å¿uch a Å¿evere Captivity; that he that lately was a Å¿lave to Infidels, that worÅ¿hip they know not what, Å¿hould now Å¿ee the Faces of ChriÅ¿tians, and joyn with them in WorÅ¿hiping the true God; and to him firÅ¿t he offer'd up the Sacrifice of hearty thankÅ¿giving, that had Å¿ent his Angel to redeem him from Å¿o cruel a bondage. When he came on board, his hair was very long, and his skin tawny (Malatto-like) having gone naked all the time he was there, and frequently anointing himÅ¿elf with Palm-Oyl he looked like a Tawny Moore; but immediately the Seamen aboard with ChriÅ¿tian-like hearts, apparelled him. The
MaÅ¿ter commanded to hoiÅ¿t Å¿ail, and having a fair wind, they Å¿ailed to Barbadoes, where Captain Royden was to tarry Å¿ome time; but the Relator earneÅ¿tly deÅ¿iring to go to his Native Country, and his Relations, got paÅ¿Å¿age to the Downs, in the Katherine of London, Captain South Commander, which through Gods goodneÅ¿s in a few weeks arrived in the Downs, where the Relator was put on Å¿hore to his Unkle Mr. Richard Watts of Deal, his great joy and Å¿atisfaction, who took this relation from his own mouth.

div.head: The Relation of Dr. William JohnÅ¿on, concerning a moÅ¿t Remarkable Sea-Deliverance; in his own words.
div.p:
27. We went aboard from Harwich, on Michaelmas day, Sept. 29. 1648. in the William and John of IpÅ¿wich, Daniel Morgan, MaÅ¿ter, and having a fair wind, we Å¿et Sail; I being Sea-Å¿ick, went to bed, but about four a Clock in the Afternoon, the MaÅ¿ter of the Ship came into our Cabin with more haÅ¿t than he was wont, which made me ask him whither all was well, who like a tender-hearted man, who is loth to tell his dying Friend, that he is Å¿o nigh his end, replyed all is well, yet when I Å¿aw him Å¿hift himÅ¿elf with Å¿uch
haÅ¿t, I roÅ¿e from my Bed, and crawled upon the Deck, where I Å¿aw a Å¿ad Å¿pectacle, the Ship having Å¿prung a leak, or rather a plank, was ready to Å¿ink, upon which, every man was affrighted, one was at his Prayers, another wringing his Hands, a third his eyes Å¿hedding of tears, when he had no need of more Å¿alt water; but after this, they fell to work, but were buÅ¿ie in doing nothing: The MaÅ¿ters Mate, who went to Å¿earch the Leak, told us with a Å¿ad countenance, trembling hands, gnaÅ¿hing of Teeth, a quivering Tongue, and words half Å¿poken, That the Leak could not be Å¿topt, and the water came in Å¿o faÅ¿t upon us, that we muÅ¿t periÅ¿h in this moment. Upon which we preÅ¿ently caÅ¿t out our Long-boat, and Å¿hot off eight or nine Guns to another Ship, who came out with us, to come to our relief, then with Å¿ome difficulty we all got into the Boat, and God be thanked, came clear of the Ship, whoÅ¿e Å¿ails now lay flat upon the Water, and now we were rowing we know not whither, for the other Ship came not to our relief, which made us have hard thoughts of them without cauÅ¿e, for we underÅ¿tood that both the Ship, and all the men periÅ¿hed in the Å¿ame hour. Now were we
without all hope, for it blew half a Å¿torm, and we were in a Å¿mall VeÅ¿Å¿el, many Leagues from the Shore, without CompaÅ¿s, or proviÅ¿ion to Å¿uÅ¿tain us, being Å¿tarved likewiÅ¿e with Cold, as well as for want of Victuals, having nothing in our Boat, but a Å¿mall Kettle which Å¿erved to caÅ¿t out the water, and three bags of pieces of eight of three hundred pound Sterling, which would neither feed us, nor keep us warm; in this diÅ¿treÅ¿s we went to Prayers, and it pleaÅ¿ed God to hear us, and Å¿end a Ship to us, even in the moment of Death, which we endeavoured to come to, and he likewiÅ¿e to us, but the Å¿torm was Å¿o great, we could not reach one another, though when it was dark, he hung out a light, and we to let him know we were alive, ordered that when a wave took us up, we Å¿hould give a great Å¿hout, which we did Å¿o loud, that I believe our cry was heard to Heaven, for by Gods miraculous aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance we got near the Ship, and Å¿oon after, all Å¿afe into it; the next day it blew fair for Norway, whither we were bound, and about twelve at noon we Å¿aw the CoaÅ¿t, which being ragged, and full of Rocks, we reÅ¿olved to Å¿tay till next morning before we went in, and then Å¿ate down to meat, and eat very
heartily, being kindly entertain'd by the honeÅ¿t Norwegian; about ten a clock at night, we laid us down to reÅ¿t, after having prayed, and Å¿et our watch, but immediately this our Å¿econd Ship ran with full Sails upon a Rock, and gave Å¿o great a Crack, as was able to awake the moÅ¿t dead aÅ¿leep among us, and the Marriners cryed out, Mercy, Mercy, it pleaÅ¿ed God, that the Ship Å¿truck it Å¿elf Å¿o faÅ¿t in the cleft of a Rock, with her Bow over the main Rock, that the former part of her Å¿tood firm, but breaking in the Å¿torm, one of the Sea-men leaped from the bow of the Ship, upon the Rock, with a Rope in his hand, which was faÅ¿tened to one of our MaÅ¿ts, and held it with Å¿o Å¿tiff a hand, that another Å¿lipt down by it, and Å¿o all our Company that eÅ¿caped, being Twenty Eight in number, came Å¿afe to the Rock; I was the laÅ¿t that came down the Ship that way, for in that very moment Å¿he gave way, which the MaÅ¿ter perceiving, who was Å¿till aboard, made lamentable moan to us, to help him, which we endeavoured to the utmoÅ¿t, but the Ship broke, and Å¿unk immediately; there was this good man, and four of the Marriners drowned; I Å¿aw the MaÅ¿ter, with a light in his hand fall
into the Sea, the Å¿addeÅ¿t Å¿ight that I ever yet beheld in this world, and that which pierced my very Soul, to Å¿ee him that Å¿aved our Lives, loÅ¿e his own: Now were we in the dark, upon the Rock, but knew not where, our feet being cut upon the Å¿harp Å¿tones, at length, we happened of a hole in the Rock, which was a warm Å¿helter againÅ¿t the wind; and when morning came, where we could Å¿ee no Land, only had a Glimps of the CoaÅ¿t of Norway at a great diÅ¿tance; We grew hungry, but had nothing to fiÅ¿h, but our Arms, with which we drew up Å¿ome Å¿mall MuÅ¿cles, and they we eat heartily, but we burnt with thirÅ¿t, and I would have given all I had for a draught of freÅ¿h water, which would have been more welcome than the Gold of Ophir, though nothing is Å¿o mean in our eÅ¿teem; but we were forced to drink Salt-water, which increaÅ¿ed our thirÅ¿t; we now Å¿aw a Ship coming towards us with full Sails, and we waved our hats to them, but they went off, and never came near us; we betook our Å¿elves to our old Remedy, Prayers, the Danes firÅ¿t Å¿inging one of
â¢â¢ ther's PÅ¿alms, fell to their Prayers, and I prayed as long as I was able to Å¿peak, and then lay'd my Å¿elf down on the Rock,
thinking I Å¿hould riÅ¿e no more in this World: But I overheard one of the Sea-men Å¿ay, Let us make a Raft, and venture to Sea, I had rather be drowned than lye here and be Å¿tarved; They all concluded of it, though dangerous, and the Sea having fallen from the Rock, had left our Sails, MaÅ¿ts, and Anchors, with part of the Ship thereon, wherewith they Å¿oon made a Å¿light Boat, and it being a great calm, the reÅ¿t paÅ¿t through the beaches with four men in it, and had it touched only on them, they would have rent it in pieces, however through Gods goodneÅ¿s, they arrived Å¿afe in Norway, and returned with Å¿everal Boats, Å¿o that we came all of us once more to Land, and were entertained at an honeÅ¿t Lutheran ParÅ¿ons houÅ¿e, where after we had continued for Å¿ome days, with little money and much thanks we parted, and came to Frederick ãâã , where the People run after us in the Street, and with compaÅ¿Å¿ionate Eyes gave us what we wanted, without asking; from thence we went to OÅ¿terÅ¿on â¢â¢ , and there went aboard an EngliÅ¿h Ship, we had not been above two or three ãâã at Sea, but there was a Å¿ad deÅ¿traction, the Marriners again crying for Mercy, Mercy, for we had almoÅ¿t
fallen foul on a Rock under water, which we did not Å¿py till we were upon it, but by the mercy of God, we Å¿ailed cloÅ¿e by â¢ t, and yet eÅ¿caped it, the leaÅ¿t touch of â¢ t had been our ruine; about noon we â¢ ame clear of all the Rocks on the CoaÅ¿t of Norway, and were Å¿ailing for England, with a fair Gale of Wind, but in this proÅ¿perity, another Å¿ad accident befel us, â¢ his third Ship Å¿prang a leak, and began â¢ o Å¿wim within, as well as without, and we had no way to relieve our Å¿elves, but â¢ y pumping (for the Leak could not be â¢ ound) which we did day and night, or four or five days together, when it â¢ leaÅ¿ed God, we came Å¿afe, though in a â¢ reat deal of danger, becauÅ¿e of our otten Ship; into Yarmouth Road, for the â¢ ind being very high, had like to have â¢ riven us upon a Scotch VeÅ¿Å¿el, who cryed â¢ ut as well as we, but we happily miÅ¿t â¢â¢ m, and Å¿o Å¿afely arrived in Yarmouth
â¢ own, through the wonderful mercy of God. Deus NobiÅ¿cum.

div.head: The great Dangers, and Merciful Deliverances of William Okely and his Company from Slavery in a Canvas Boat, &c.
div.p:
In the Year 1639. We took Ship at
â¢ aveÅ¿end, in the Mary of London, Mr.
Boarder MaÅ¿ter, bound for the IÅ¿le of Providence in the WeÅ¿t-Indies, five weeks we lay in the Downs, waiting for a wind, and then we Å¿et Sail, and came to an Anchor near the IÅ¿le of Wight, but by this time all the Beer in our Ship Å¿tunk, and we were forced to throw it overboard, and Å¿o take in Vinegar to mix with Water for our Voyage; the next Lords day we Å¿et Sail again, and coming between the IÅ¿land, and the main Land, we Å¿tuck faÅ¿ â¢ in the Sands, but the Tide coming in â¢ heaved us off: the Å¿ixth day after ou â¢ Å¿etting Sail from the IÅ¿le of Wight, we diÅ¿covered three Turks men of War, wh â¢ chaÅ¿ed us, and at break of day boarde â¢ and took us; having kept us clo â¢â¢ PriÅ¿oners at Sea, at the end of five or Å¿ix weeks, they brought us to Algiers, when I was Å¿old for a Å¿lave the firÅ¿t Market da â¢ to a Patron, who told me, I muÅ¿t allow him two Dollars a Month, and live aÅ¿hore where I would, and get it when I could, though I knew not where t â¢ levy the leaÅ¿t Mite of it: Wandring u â¢ and down I met with an EngliÅ¿h-man
ãâã his little Shop, who Traded with T â¢
bacco, and a few other things; I beca â¢â¢ his Partner with a little Money I h â¢â¢ reÅ¿erved, and a Å¿mall modicum my Patr â¢â¢
had allowed me for my Å¿tock; Here I got money and hired a Celler, where I laid up Å¿ome other of my Goods; when weary of my Å¿lavery, I formed a deÅ¿ign for my Liberty, and communicated it to John Anthony Carpenter, William Adams Brick-layer, John Jephs Seaman, John a Carpenter, and two others, men of able Bodies, and uÅ¿eful in the intended project, which was to contrive the Model of a Boat, which being formed in parcels, and afterward put together, might be the means of our eÅ¿cape: They approved the PropoÅ¿al, and in my Cellar we began our work, we provided firÅ¿t a piece of Timber of twelve foot long to make the Keel, but becauÅ¿e it was impoÅ¿Å¿ible to convey it of that length out of the City, but it muÅ¿t be Å¿een and Å¿uÅ¿pected; we therefore cut it in two pieces and fitted it for jointing juÅ¿t at the middle, and then we provided Ribs, after which we made the Boat Water-tight, and becauÅ¿e boards would require much hammering, and that noiÅ¿e was like to betray us, we bought as much Å¿trong Canvas as would cover our Boat twice over upon the Convex of the Carine; we provided alÅ¿o as much Pitch, Tar, and Tallow, as would Å¿erve to make it a kind of Tarpawling Cerecloth
to Å¿waddle the Naked Body of our Infant Boat; of two Pipe Å¿taves Å¿awed at the Corners, we made two things to Å¿erve for Oars, and for our ProviÅ¿ion, we had a little Bread, and two Leather Bottles full of freÅ¿h Water, we alÅ¿o remembered to buy as much Canvas as would Å¿erve for a Sail, we carried out theÅ¿e in parts and parcels fitted them together in the Valley about half a mile from the Sea, whither Four of our Company carried the Boat on their Shoulders, and the reÅ¿t followed them, at the Sea-Å¿ide we Å¿tript, put our clothes into the Boat, and carried it and them as far into the Sea as we could wade, and then all Å¿even got into the Boat, but finding Å¿he was over laden, two of the Sea-men were content to Å¿tay on Å¿hore; having bid them farewel, we lanched out, June 30. 1644. The Bill of Lading was John Anthony, William Adams, John Jephs, John the Carpenter, and William Okely; Four of us wrought continually at the Oar, the Fifth was to free the Boat of that Water, which by degrees leaked through our Canvas, our Bread was Å¿oon Å¿poiled with the Å¿oaking in the Salt-water, our FreÅ¿h-water Å¿tunk of the Tanned Skins, and Owze, yet we complained not, three days with good
Husbandry our Bread laÅ¿ted us, but then Pale Famine Å¿tar'd us in the Face; Water indeed we might have, but it muÅ¿t be Salt, out of the Sea, or that which had been Å¿train'd through our own Bodies, and that we choÅ¿e of the two; but we muÅ¿t not have that after a while, unleÅ¿s we would accept of the other firÅ¿t; and the miÅ¿ery was, that did not aÅ¿Å¿wage our ThirÅ¿t, but increaÅ¿e it; the Wind too, for Å¿ome time was full againÅ¿t us, but God rebuked it, and made it our Friend; a Å¿econd inconvenience was, that our Labour was without intermiÅ¿Å¿ion; and a third, the extremity of the Heat by day, the Å¿eaÅ¿on raging hot, the beginning of July, and we wanted freÅ¿h-water to cool the Heat, our Labour made it inÅ¿upportable to our Bodies, and our little hope made it as grievous to our Souls; one help we had, a poor one, he that emptied the Boat, threw the Water on the Bodies of the other to cool them; but our Bodies thus Å¿chorched and cooled roÅ¿e up in BliÅ¿ters all over; great pain we felt, great dangers we were in, great miÅ¿eries we indur'd, great wants we were under, and had nothing but a little hope, food, and Å¿trength: If any Ask by what Directions we Steered our courÅ¿e to Mayorck,
whither we deÅ¿ign'd to go; for the day a Pocket Dial did Å¿upply the place of a CompaÅ¿s, by Night the Stars when they appear'd, and when not, we gueÅ¿Å¿ed our way by the motion of the Clouds: Four days and nights were we in this woful plight; on the fifth, all hope that we Å¿hould be Å¿av'd was periÅ¿h'd, Å¿o that we left off our Labour, becauÅ¿e we had no Å¿trength left, only we emptied the Boat of Water; but then God Å¿ent us Å¿ome Relief, for as we lay hulling up and down, we diÅ¿cover'd a TortoiÅ¿e, not far from us aÅ¿leep in the Sea; had Drake diÅ¿cover'd the SpaniÅ¿h Fleet, he could not have more Rejoyc'd; we took up our Oars, Å¿ilently rowed to our Prey, took it into the Boat with Great Triumph; we cut off her Head, and let her Bleed into a Pot, we drank the Blood, eat the Liver, and Å¿ucked the fleÅ¿h: it wonderfully refreÅ¿hed our Spirits, and we picked up Å¿ome crumbs of hope: about Noon we thought we diÅ¿cover'd Land; it's impoÅ¿Å¿ible to expreÅ¿s the joy of our raiÅ¿ed Souls at this apprehenÅ¿ion, we Wrought hard, and after further Labour were fully Å¿atisfy'd that it was Land, and proved to be Mayork, which we kept within Å¿ight of all day. July the 6th. about Ten at Night we
came under the IÅ¿land, and crept as near the Shore as we could or durÅ¿t, till we found a convenient place, where we might thruÅ¿t in our Weather-beaten Boat; when we were come to Land we were not inÅ¿enÅ¿ible of our deliverance; but though we had eÅ¿cap'd the Sea, we might die at Land; We had no Food Å¿ince we eat the Liver, and drank the Blood of the TortoiÅ¿e; therefore John Anthony and my Å¿elf were Å¿ent out to Scout abroad for FreÅ¿h-Water, becauÅ¿e we Å¿pake Å¿ome SpaniÅ¿h; We came to a Watch-Tower of the Spaniards, Å¿pake to them on the Watch, told them our Condition, earneÅ¿tly begged Å¿ome FreÅ¿h-Water, and Å¿ome Bread; he threw us down an old Mouldy Cake, but Å¿o long as it was a Cake, Hunger did not conÅ¿ider its MouldineÅ¿s; then he directed us to FreÅ¿h-Water which was hard by; We Å¿tood not telling of Stories, we remembred our Brethren left with our Boat, and obÅ¿erving the Centinels Directions, came to a Well, where there was a Pot with Å¿trings to draw with; we drank a little Water, and eat a bit of our Cake, but the paÅ¿Å¿age was Å¿o diÅ¿uÅ¿ed, that we had much ado to force our Throats to relieve our clamorous Stomachs; we return to our
Boat, and acquaint them with the Good SucceÅ¿Å¿es of our EmbaÅ¿Å¿y, and all prepare to make to the Well, Å¿o tying our Boat as faÅ¿t as we could to the Å¿hore, we left her to Mercy: Now we are at the Well which hath Water therein, and we have Å¿omething to draw, but God muÅ¿t give us a Throat to Å¿wallow; for William Adams attempting to drink, after many EÅ¿Å¿ays, was not able to Å¿wallow it, but Å¿till the Water return'd, Å¿o that he Å¿unk down to the ground, fainting, Å¿aying, I am a dead Man: but after much Å¿triving he took a little; Å¿o refreÅ¿hed with our Cake and Water, we lay by the Well Å¿ide till the Morning; when it was clear day, we again went to the Watchman, intreating him to direct us the ready way to the next HouÅ¿e or Town, where we might find relief; he civilly pointed us to one about Two Miles off, and long it was ere our BliÅ¿tering Feet could overcome the tediouÅ¿neÅ¿s of that little way: When we came thither, the honeÅ¿t Farmer moved with our Relation, Å¿ent us Bread and Water, and Olives, and Å¿eeing us Thankful Beggars, inlarged his Civility to us, called us into his HouÅ¿e, and gave us good warm Bean Pottage, which Å¿eem'd to me the moÅ¿t pleaÅ¿ant Food that ever I eat in
my Life, then we advanced to the City of Mayorck, about Ten Miles from that place; that Night we lay by a Well Å¿ide, and in the Morning we entred the Suburbs; the Vice-Roy was informed of us, and we were commanded to appear before him, who, after he had Examin'd us, and heard our Story, order'd we Å¿hould be maintain'd at his own CoÅ¿t, till we could have PaÅ¿Å¿age to our own Countrey, But our EngliÅ¿h Ships Å¿eldom Trading thither, we Petition'd the Vice-Roy for PaÅ¿Å¿age in the King of Spain's Gallies, which were in the Road bound for Alicant, which he graciouÅ¿ly granted us; after Å¿ome other Troubles we met with contrary Winds, and it was five Weeks ere we could reach the Downs, where we arriv'd in Sept. 1644. The Commander of the Ship was Captain Smith of Rotherhithe, Mr. Thomas Saunders, my Wives Brother, being in Mayorck not long after we came from thence, Å¿aw our Boat hung for a Monument upon the Å¿ide of the Great Church there; and Mr. Robert Hales was there 1671. and aÅ¿Å¿ures me, that he Å¿aw the Naked Ribs and Skeleton of it then hanging in the Å¿ame place. Wanly's HiÅ¿t. Man, p. 642.

div.head: The Merciful PreÅ¿ervation and Deliverance of Captain BloÅ¿e and his Å¿hips Company, who were CaÅ¿t away in an IÅ¿land of Ice near RuÅ¿Å¿ia, this preÅ¿ent year 1697.
div.p:
October the 7th. 1696. We came from Archangel in RuÅ¿Å¿ia in the Riga Merchant, Burthen 300 Tuns, 18 Guns, Samuel BloÅ¿e Commander. The 8th we had the Wind at North WeÅ¿t by WeÅ¿t, we plied to Windward, and it blew very hard; the 10th we took two Reefs in our TopÅ¿ails; the 12th we took in our TopÅ¿ails, and Reefed CoÅ¿ts; the 13th about One in the Morning we Sprung a Leak, in Å¿o much that we were forced to Å¿et both our Pumps to Work, and bear away before the Wind; yet Å¿till the Water increaÅ¿ed; and the 14th we cut our Main-Sail from the Yard, and let him fly over-board, the Weather being Å¿o exceÅ¿Å¿ive thick by reaÅ¿on of the extraordinary much Snow that then fell, that we could not Å¿ee the Land, nor any place where we could run our Ship AÅ¿hore to Å¿ave our Lives; The 15th in the Morning, about One of the Clock, by Fortune, unexpected of us, before we Å¿ee any Land, we Å¿truck upon an IÅ¿land, called by the
RuÅ¿Å¿es, MuÅ¿Å¿oves, lying in the MiÅ¿Å¿en Gulf, which by the Miraculous hand of God ãâ¦ã gotten well aÅ¿hore, for as God of his wonderful goodneÅ¿s Å¿o order'd it, we Å¿truck about High Water, and as the Water fell away, our Ship dryed, Å¿o that we got all Å¿afe to Land without any harm; and if it had pleaÅ¿ed God we happen'd ever Å¿o little, either to one Å¿ide or the other, we Å¿hould have all periÅ¿h'd amongÅ¿t the IÅ¿lands of Ice. When we got all aÅ¿hore, we made us a Tent, and when it was Day, looking about us, Å¿aw Å¿omething like HouÅ¿es; Å¿o our Captain and a Dutch Merchant PaÅ¿Å¿enger that we had on Board of our Ship, and our Doctor, went to Å¿ee what they were, thinking to find Å¿ome Inhabitants, but they could â¢ ind none: then we went Aboard our Ship, and got all our Beef aÅ¿hore that we could find, about One hundred Weight of Bisket Bread, which was all the Bread we could find; then we Calculated that our Beef at Four Pieces a day, would Å¿erve us till the middle of May, and every Man one Bisket a Day; but that would laÅ¿t but a Å¿mall time: BeÅ¿ides, we got a Å¿hore Three Boxes of Candles, which was a great comfort to us in our neceÅ¿Å¿ity, by reaÅ¿on we
had not above Three hours Day. Then we got all our things we had Å¿aved to the HouÅ¿e that we Å¿aw; and going about diÅ¿cover'd a great many more HouÅ¿es, and we went to them to Å¿ee what we could find, expecting to Å¿ee Å¿ome People, but there was none but empty Cask, Å¿o we came home to the place that we had carried our things to again; but, as God would have it, juÅ¿t againÅ¿t the HouÅ¿e that we had taken for our Habitation, in the Snow, we Å¿aw Two Cask, and we went and found them both full of Rye Meal, which was a Joy beyond meaÅ¿ure to us in our Extremity; and then we found another Cask with a Kneeding-Tub in it: December the FirÅ¿t, the Dutch Merchant, and Four more of our hands went out and took a CompaÅ¿s, and ProviÅ¿ion with them, upon DiÅ¿covery, hoping to Å¿ee Å¿ome body to Å¿peak to, that we might know where we were, but they could find no Inhabitants, the CourÅ¿e they Å¿teered was S. E. but when they came to turn back, their CompaÅ¿s unhung, and they not minding it, went up and down a long time, and at length came to the Å¿ame place where they were when they firÅ¿t turned back; then they looked more earneÅ¿tly upon their CompaÅ¿s, and
found it unhung, they hung it, and came the direct way home again; but when they came in Å¿ight of a HouÅ¿e that was about Two Miles off of our HouÅ¿e, the Merchant and one more Travelling better than the other Three, went before, and promis'd them to make a Fire againÅ¿t they came; but the Weather being Å¿o Å¿evere, they were not able to come along, but were Starved with the Cold before they could get up to us: So the Lord, of his great Mercy, made ProviÅ¿ion for us until the FirÅ¿t of March, it being a Sabbath day, and we at our Devotion, one of our Boys being at another Ho â¢ Å¿e Boiling of our Victuals, Å¿aw Å¿ome Men upon the IÅ¿land, he fell down, being much Å¿urpriz'd, but Å¿oon got up again, and run and told us; upon which we left our Prayers, and run to Å¿ee what they were; our Merchant could Å¿peak the Language, which was the preÅ¿ervation of all our Lives, for otherways they would have Murther'd us for breaking down their HouÅ¿es, and Eating their ProviÅ¿ions that we found upon the IÅ¿land, for they would not be perÅ¿waded but we were Pirats and Robbers, by reaÅ¿on that we werre Building of a Small VeÅ¿Å¿el for our own Security, of carrying us to the
Main when the Ice broke up; but our Merchant Å¿peaking their Language, perÅ¿waded them, and promiÅ¿ed them to make them Satisfaction for what Dammage we had done them; for we broke down Two of their HouÅ¿es for Firing: So they â¢â¢ rned us out of our HouÅ¿es, and took our Meal from us. The Men that came over were in Number 500, Ten Men in a Boat, they came there to kill Seales: They asked us what we had Å¿een? We told them, Nothing but Two Ravens. They made very Å¿trange of it, and would not believe it: For they told us, That none of them could live there but Six Weeks in the Year, whether they catcht FiÅ¿h or not, the IÅ¿land was Å¿o Haunted. Soon after the RuÅ¿Å¿ians came there, that Man that Å¿aved his Life, and got well home with the Merchant, when the other Three were Starved with the Cold Died, that was Four that was Dead, our Complyment at firÅ¿t was 27, but then we had but 23 Living: Then our Merchant went to the RuÅ¿Å¿ians, and deÅ¿ired them to put us â¢ ver, and he would Å¿atisfie them for it: They granted we Å¿hould have Six Boats, and 60 Men to Drag us over the Ice, for it was Seven Leagues from the Main, and
all full of IÅ¿lands of Ice between, inÅ¿omuch that they were 24 hours coming over when they came upon the Å¿aid IÅ¿land: But it pleaÅ¿ed the Lord Å¿o to order it that after they had dragg'd us over Two Å¿mall IÅ¿lands of Ice, that as God parted the Red-Sea for the Children of IÅ¿rael to paÅ¿s through, Å¿o he parted the Ice from us, inÅ¿omuch that we got over in Six houres times, which the RuÅ¿sians told us was never Å¿o before. But when we came over we lay where there was 1000 Men a FiÅ¿hing, The firÅ¿t Night: and the next Morning we hired Sledges to drag us to Å¿ome place Inhabited: The BeaÅ¿ts that dragg'd the Sledges along they call Roeys, they are like Dear, but larger: We were forc'd to be Dragg'd, we could not Travel our Limbs were Å¿o diÅ¿abled with the Cold before we got off the aforeÅ¿aid IÅ¿land: beÅ¿ides the Snow was of Å¿uch a vaÅ¿t thickneÅ¿s, and Å¿o hard Frozen, that we could find no Path, if we could Travel never Å¿o well, If the Shamakes, as they call them, had not Å¿hown us the way; the firÅ¿t Night of our Journey upon the Sledges our Carpenters Mate died, Å¿o we made a Hole in the Snow and put him in, and left him. Then our
Captain, and the Merchant, and the Doctor, being but Å¿ingle in a Sledge, and we near double, went faÅ¿ter than us to the next Town to provide Victuals and freÅ¿h Sledges for us againÅ¿t we came; and when we came to that Town we got Sledges that had HorÅ¿es to draw them along, Å¿o we Rid Night and Day till we came to Archangel; the Third day of our Travels another of our Men Died, and the Fifth day another; the former we Buryed in the Ground, becauÅ¿e we were nigh a Town, but the other we Buryed in the Snow: So that when we came to Archangel, out of our 27 Men, we had but 20 left. March the 17th we came off the aforeÅ¿aid IÅ¿land, and we Travell'd Night and Day, except the firÅ¿t Night, until the 25th of the Å¿ame Month. Two days after we came to Archangel we loÅ¿t another Man. At Archangel our Captain got Stoves for us to inhabit in, and Å¿ent us ProviÅ¿ion, where we remain'd till the 6th day of June, when there came in Six Sail of Hollanders, being the FirÅ¿t that came that year, who divided us amongÅ¿t them, and brought us to Greenland, and from thence Å¿ome of us were brought to Holland, and Å¿ome to Hamborough, from whence Sixteen
of us got PaÅ¿Å¿age to England, where we Arriv'd the Fifteenth of November, 1697. Two went to the Straits, and our Dutch Merchant tarried in Holland.
This Account is given by Francis Lee, who was BoatÅ¿wain of the Ship, and AtteÅ¿ted by others now Living in London.

div.head: THE Seaman's Preacher; OR, Sea-Dangers and Deliverances Improv'd; in a SERMON.

q.p: 18. And being exceedingly toÅ¿Å¿ed with a TempeÅ¿t, the next day they lightned the Ship.
19. And the third day, we caÅ¿t out with our own hands, the tackling of the Ship.
20. And when neither Sun nor Stars appeared, and no Å¿mall TempeÅ¿t lay on us, all hope that we Å¿hould be Å¿aved, was then taken away.

div.p:
IN this Chapter we have a full Narrative of Paul's Voyage to Rome, in all the circumÅ¿tances of it; it Å¿eems Paul
kept a Journal, and Å¿o Recorded this memorable Voyage for the uÅ¿e of Å¿ucceeding Generations. 1. We have the occaÅ¿ion of his Voyage, (viz.) Paul being then a Sufferer and a PriÅ¿oner, he appeals to CaeÅ¿ar, and Å¿o is Å¿ent to Rome, and there bears a faithful TeÅ¿timony for JeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, (verÅ¿. 1.) 2. We have the Dangers that occurred in the Voyage, and theÅ¿e are alÅ¿o carefully Commemorated (verÅ¿. 9.) Now much time was Å¿pent, and Sailing was now dangerous, becauÅ¿e the FaÅ¿t was already paÅ¿t: This was the yearly Fast of the Jews, on which the attonement for all the people was made by the High-PrieÅ¿t, in the holy of holies; which day was the 10. of the 7th Month, (Lev. 16. 29.) which partly agreed with our September and October, in which time the Sea, was not Sailed in, by the Ancients, until the beginning of March, becauÅ¿e of the Å¿hortneÅ¿s of the days, and the violence of the TempeÅ¿ts, they were prone to in thoÅ¿e Parts, this is the Å¿enÅ¿e of Interpreters upon the place. 1. Danger of the Voyage we read of, is this, the winds were contrary, (verÅ¿. 4.) this is Å¿poken of the Voyage of the DiÅ¿ciples, The winds were contrary. 2. Danger, there aroÅ¿e not only a contrary wind,
but a violent wind, called an Euroclydon, (verÅ¿. 14.) Å¿ome read it a Whirle-wind, but it is ment of an EaÅ¿t-wind, which raiÅ¿es the Sea mightily. 3. The TempeÅ¿t was Å¿o great and violent upon them, that they were glad to let the Ship drive, (verÅ¿. 15.)
3. We have not only the Danger in this Voyage, but their marvelous Deliverance and PreÅ¿ervation; for they came off all of them with their lives, (verÅ¿. 44.) the particulars whereof you may Å¿ee.

In the Text we have three things obÅ¿ervable. 1. Their endeavors in this great diÅ¿treÅ¿s to preÅ¿erve themÅ¿elves. 1. They lightned the Ship, and what was it Å¿he was laden with? it was Wheat, (verÅ¿. 38.) They lightned the Ship, and caÅ¿t the Wheat into the Sea; thus did Jonah's Mariners caÅ¿t out the Wares. Alas, what are theÅ¿e things, but lumber to lives? if it were Gold, it muÅ¿t go for Life. Skin for skin and all that a man hath will he give for his life. Then what Å¿hould a man give for his Soul? what will a man give for his Soul? what will a man give in exchange for his Soul? 2. Endeavor; they caÅ¿t out the Tackling of their Ship; any thing they part with to Å¿ave their lives, though never Å¿o uÅ¿eful to them; even that which was
neceÅ¿Å¿ary for their Voyage, they are under a neceÅ¿Å¿ity to part with it, for the preÅ¿ervation of their lives.

2. We have their Dangers as well as Endeavors. 1. It is expreÅ¿t in the violence of the TempeÅ¿t; they were exceedingly toÅ¿Å¿ed with a TempeÅ¿t. 2. It was dark weather, neither Sun nor Stars appeared, which uÅ¿ed to be great comforts and helps to poor men at Sea. 3. Their Danger is expreÅ¿t in this, they were brought to the brink of the black pit of DeÅ¿pair; all Hope now was taken away. O what a Å¿ad diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed condition was this! their Hope, which is called the Anchor of the Soul, yea which is the Sheet-Anchor of the Soul, was loÅ¿t; they gave all their lives over for gone and loÅ¿t: And oh, what could now a company of men do that had loÅ¿t their Hopes and Hearts? could theÅ¿e that had loÅ¿t their Hopes find their hands? they were now Å¿aying, as the Jews did in their Captivity, Our Hope is loÅ¿t, we are cut off for our parts, (Ezek. 37. 11.)

3. We have their Deliverance and PreÅ¿ervation, coming in at Å¿uch a time and Å¿eaÅ¿on as this was; now that they are brought to an extremity, God makes it his opportunity; and now that all hope
of being Å¿aved is taken away, Å¿alvation will be moÅ¿t Å¿eaÅ¿onable: and now the Angel appears to Paul, and tells him, all their lives are enÅ¿ured, only the Å¿hip Å¿hall be loÅ¿t.

list.head: ObÅ¿ervations are theÅ¿e:
list.item: 1. Dangers and Deliverances are to be carefully recorded and remembred; therefore Paul takes an account of both, here in this Voyage.
2. Salvations and Deliverances many times are not Å¿ent, until perÅ¿ons be left hopeleÅ¿s in themÅ¿elves.

div.p: I Å¿hall Å¿peak a little to both theÅ¿e upon this preÅ¿ent occaÅ¿ion, that what you read here, may be remarked and remembred.
1. Dangers and Deliverances are to be carefully recorded and remembred. This ObÅ¿ervation hath two parts: 1. Dangers are to be remembred. 2. Deliverances are to be remembred.

Thus the Lords poor people uÅ¿ed to do in all Ages: When Jacob was in danger of his Brother EÅ¿au, you Å¿ee how he commemorates it, and gives us an exact narrative of it, and tells us how he feared him:
Lord, I fear my Brother EÅ¿au, (PÅ¿al. 34. 4.) How often was David in danger by Saul, who was his Å¿worn Enemy? and how many PÅ¿alms have we, taking occaÅ¿ion to remember what danger he was in, and how comfortably he was brought off: I Å¿ought the Lord, and he heard me; and delivered me out of all my fears. (2 Cor. 1. 9, 10.) As Paul tells the Corinthians what danger they were in; they were preÅ¿t out of meaÅ¿ure, out of Å¿trength, in Å¿o much that they deÅ¿paired of life, &c. And Å¿o at Sea as well as Land, he would have dangers remembred; how that they go up to the Heaven one while, and Å¿ink into the deeps another; their Soul melted becauÅ¿e of trouble, and they at their wits ends, &c. Peter's danger at Sea is recorded, when he began to Å¿ink, and cried out, MaÅ¿ter, Å¿ave me, or I periÅ¿h, (Matth. 14. 28, 29, 30.) And the DiÅ¿ciples, when they cried o â¢ t, CareÅ¿t thou not that we periÅ¿h? (Mark 4. 38.) It is obÅ¿erved the Ship now was full, and now comes Å¿alvation and deliverance. Here was their danger recorded, the Ship was full, and ChriÅ¿t aÅ¿leep in the hinder part of the Ship.

list.item: 1. Query is, How Dangers Å¿hould be remembred?

div.p: 1. Dangers Å¿hould be remembred, conÅ¿idering we may come into them again. Many when dangers are not, they Å¿ing to their Souls that Å¿ong, and delude themÅ¿elves, The bitterneÅ¿s of Death is paÅ¿t; they think they are out of one Å¿trom, and they Å¿hall never come in Å¿uch another. JuÅ¿t as perÅ¿ons do with their SickneÅ¿s at Land, Å¿o many do with their Dangers at Sea, if God bring them off: O they grow hardned and Å¿ecure again. But if God hath brought home one dangerous Voyage, we Å¿hould think, it may be the next will be as dangerous; Have I eÅ¿caped one at Sea, one at Land? if I do not improve it, if I do not walk Å¿uitable under it, O how eaÅ¿ily can God bring me into another. You never were in Å¿uch Dangers, but you may come to the like again, whether at Sea or Land.

2. Dangers Å¿hould be remembred with conÅ¿ideration to the greatneÅ¿s of them; great things Å¿hould be remembred, a great God, great Mercies, great Deliverances, great Sins, and great Dangers. How Å¿hould we think, O what a Danger was I in at this time by Å¿uch a Storm at Sea! by Å¿uch a SickneÅ¿s aÅ¿hore! not only my Life in danger, but Lord, was not my Soul in danger? was I fit to die at
Å¿uch a time? had I gotten an intereÅ¿t in ChriÅ¿t, if I had been caÅ¿t away at Å¿uch a time? Men think dangers great for their Bodies, but they do not think them Å¿o for their Souls; they think them great for their Ships, for their EÅ¿tates, but they do not think them Å¿o for their Eternal conditions; O, had not my Body, Soul, Ship, and all periÅ¿hed together. And was not this a great danger? thy Souls danger was the greateÅ¿t danger; hadÅ¿t thou been drowned at Å¿uch a time, thy Soul had been Å¿hipwrackt to all Eternity.

3. Dangers Å¿hould be remembred with conÅ¿ideration to their Å¿uddenneÅ¿s; how many times do they come Å¿uddenly upon us? As there is Å¿udden fear, Å¿o there is Å¿udden danger. When the Lord Å¿ends the Winds out of his TreaÅ¿ury Å¿uddenly, and threatens men at Sea with Å¿udden deÅ¿truction, when deÅ¿olation Å¿eems to come as a Whirl-wind, &c. we Å¿hould think, What if Å¿udden death had come upon me, what a condition was my poor Soul in? what a dreadful thing would it have been if I had been Å¿urpriÅ¿ed on a Å¿udden, and Å¿ent into an Eternal condition, in the twinkling of an eye? I, to be threatned to be Å¿wallowed
up, only with a formal God have mercy upon thee in thy mouth; not to have time to pray, repent, reflect upon thy paÅ¿t life: O what a Å¿ad thing is this?

4. We Å¿hould think of our Danger with conÅ¿ideration to the frames of our heart â¢ what frames of heart we were then under. 1. To the frames of our hearts when in our dangers. 2. The frames of our hearts when brought from under them. 1. The frames of the heart when in and under them: were not you under great fears and hurries of Soul? it may be, not knowing how it would go with your Souls, if you had gone off the Å¿tage of this life at the preÅ¿ent. David when he was in danger, took eÅ¿pecial notice of the frame of his Å¿pirit; Innumerable evils have compaÅ¿Å¿ed me about. (PÅ¿al. 40. 12. 13.) He was compaÅ¿Å¿ed about on every Å¿ide with danger; and how was it with him then? he calls to mind, Mine iniquities have taken hold upon me, Å¿o that I am not able to look up, 57. 7.) And what then? O Å¿ee how he praysâª Be pleaÅ¿ed, O Lord, to deliver me; O Lord make haÅ¿t to help me. Remember what the frames of our hearts were in our dangers, in reference to our fears; and Å¿econdly, what in reference to our faith
Å¿o alÅ¿o did David, when purÅ¿ued in danger by Saul. My heart is fixed, my heart is fixed; I will Å¿ing and give praiÅ¿e. We are to remember our fears under our dangers, that we may be prepared better for future tryals; we are to remember our faith under dangers paÅ¿t, that we may be encouraged for the time to come in after Å¿traits.

2. We are to remember our frames of Å¿pirit when God brings us out of our dangers; how then we were melted with the preÅ¿ent Å¿enÅ¿e of the mercy; as thoÅ¿e IÅ¿raelites, when God brought them out of danger, they believed God, they Å¿ang and gave praiÅ¿e; O what reÅ¿olutions were there then upon the Soul to be given up anew to God; to walk before the Lord in the light of the living. Thus alÅ¿o did David, when brought out of danger; Thy vows are upon me, O God, &c. and at another time, The Lord preÅ¿erveth the Å¿imple: I was brought low, &c. and thou helpedÅ¿t me, (PÅ¿al. 56. 12, 13.) And then what a frame of heart was upon him? Return unto thy reÅ¿t, O my Soul, &c. (PÅ¿al. 116. 6, 7.) Then he was all for returning to God: O now there was freÅ¿h endearments betwixt the Soul and God. TheÅ¿e we are to remember, that
we may not wear totally the Å¿enÅ¿e of them off our Å¿pirits.

5. We Å¿hould remember our dangers, with conÅ¿ideration to the frequency of them; how frequently we were in them. Paul remembred this, in Perils by Sea often, in Perils by the Heathen, &c. (2 Cor. 11. 26.) O how often have we been near Drowning, near Taking, near Sinking, near Dying, and yet God brought us off; theÅ¿e things we Å¿hould call to mind often; go out upon dangerous Voyages, and often come home; the oftner and more frequent our dangers, the more Å¿hould we think upon them.

2. We Å¿hould Remember our Deliverances, but how? 1. We Å¿hould Remember them, Å¿o as to admire them; thus did the people of the Jews in Ezra, Who hath given them Å¿uch deliverance as this? O! they admire it, and write a Non-Å¿uch upon the Head of it, as David admired the goodneÅ¿s of God, when he had Å¿poken of his HouÅ¿e to come. Is this the manner of men, O God? He was in an holy ExtaÅ¿y of Heavenly admiration; Å¿o Å¿hould you Å¿ay now; to carry out, and bring home, in Å¿uch a dangerous time as this; To hide from Enemies, when Å¿ought for in Å¿uch a time Å¿uch a Voyage as this: Oh!
ãâã
am I? And what is my Fathers houÅ¿e, that he Å¿hould bring me hitherto? You Å¿hould turn the Deliverance on every Å¿ide, and admire the goodneÅ¿s of God, the wiÅ¿dom of God, the mercy of God, the power of God, the faithfulneÅ¿s of God in it, and Å¿ay, O Lord, what a Deliverance is this? What a Voyage is this? God loves to have his Mercies admired by us.

2. We Å¿hould Remember our Deliverances, to have our Hearts raiÅ¿ed up in gratitude, and thankfulneÅ¿s to God for them; Thus did David, I will pay my Vows unto the Lord, in preÅ¿ence of all his people: I will take the Cup of Salvation, and call upon the Name of the Lord, PÅ¿al. 116. 12, 13, 14. We are to remember to pay our Thank-offerings unto God, after our Deliverance from God: What, forget Å¿uch a Deliverance as this? What, not be thankful for Å¿uch a PreÅ¿ervation as this?

3. We Å¿hould Remember our Deliverances, Å¿o as to endear our Hearts to God; Thus we find David, I will love thee, O Lord, I will love the Lord dearly, ( â¢ o the Heb.) The Lord is my Rock, my FortreÅ¿s, and my Deliverer, &c. PÅ¿al. 18. 1. O! now how Å¿hould Souls, after their Deliverance; boil, and burn in Love to God!
How are we engaged to a Friend that is at any time but an InÅ¿trument in God's hand to Deliver us? And Å¿hall we be endeared to the InÅ¿trument, and not to the Author? O! How was David endeared to God, when he Å¿aid, He having Redeemed him, he would walk before the Lord in the Land of the Living, PÅ¿al. 56. ult.

4. We Å¿hould Remember our Deliverances to improve them in a way of acting Faith, when the next danger and Å¿traits comes: I will remember thee from the Land of Jordan, from the Hill MiÅ¿Å¿ar, PÅ¿al. 42. 6, 7. This was to encourage him from his former Deliverances in his future Å¿traits and exigencies. What, now diÅ¿truÅ¿t God, who hath delivered in Å¿ix Troubles, and now Å¿hall we give way to Unbelief in the Seventh? Did not holy David thus? He hath delivered me out of the Paw of the Lyon, and out of the Paw of the Bear, and he will deliver me out of the hand of the uncircumciÅ¿ed PhiliÅ¿tine. Thus Paul remembers his Deliverance from Nero. And I was delivered out of the mouth of the Lyon, and the Lord Å¿hall delive me from every evil work, 1 Tim. 4. 17, 18.

5. We Å¿hould remember our Deliverances, to be often inculcating, and imprinting
them upon our own hearts: Alas, when we receive them, they are a little freÅ¿h it may be upon our Å¿pirits, but O how Å¿oon do they die, becauÅ¿e they are not written upon our hearts; they are not Engraven there as a Man that would Remember a thing, be it a Notion, or any ReÅ¿olution, he will be often turning it over in his thoughts; Alas, if we write our Deliverances, Is it not in the DuÅ¿t? whereas we Å¿hould write them in Marble: We Å¿hould write them with a Pen of Iron, and the point of a Diamond.

1. We Å¿hould Commemorate our Dangers with our Deliverances, becauÅ¿e God gives them to that end. The Lord doth not give us our Deliverances to caÅ¿t them at our heels, nor brings us out of our Dangers, that we might forget them, as tho we had never been in any of them. God expects that we Å¿hould faithfully RegiÅ¿ter and Record them; therefore it was a great Provocation to the Lord, that the Children of IÅ¿rael Å¿o Å¿oon forgot his works: If you do but forget the kindneÅ¿s of a Friend, you think it is diÅ¿ingenious; but O then, What is it to forget that God that hath delivered you out of Å¿ix troubles, and in Å¿even troubles? God loves and expects his kindneÅ¿s Å¿hould be kept upon Record.

2. We Å¿hould Commemorate our Dangers and Deliverances, becauÅ¿e it was freely of his grace to bring us out of the one, and put us under the other; Is it not of his meer mercy that he reÅ¿cu'd and pull'd us out of our dangers? Might not we elÅ¿e been Å¿wallow'd up of them? And may not we all Å¿ay in this caÅ¿e, as the PÅ¿almiÅ¿t in that? Had it not been the Lord who was on our Å¿ide then, the waters had overwhelmed us, the Å¿tream had gone over our Soul, then the proud Waves had gone over our Soul, PÅ¿al. 124. 4, 5. May not you who have been Å¿o often deliver'd at Sea in eminent dangers Å¿ing this Songâª What, and now forget Å¿uch dangers? and caÅ¿t behind your backs Å¿uch Deliverances. Oh! the freer any favour is, the more it Å¿hould be remembred; Doth God Å¿ee any thing in us, or in our Families, more then others, to beÅ¿tow Å¿uch deliverances for? One Man goes to Sea, and he is taken; another goes to Sea, and he is Å¿unk; another goes to Sea, and he dies the Term of the Voyage; And why doth the Lord preÅ¿erve you? Is not this Free-Grace? not becauÅ¿e you are more Righteous, but becauÅ¿e he is more Gracious; And Å¿hould not this be Remembred?

3. Our Dangers and Deliverances Å¿hould be remembred, becauÅ¿e God hath gracious ends and deÅ¿igns both in the one and the other; What ends hath God to bring us into dangers? 1. He by this hath an end and deÅ¿ign to quicken up to duty; it may be there may be Å¿ome omitted duty; neglected duties often bring Men into great and eminent dangers; it may be a PerÅ¿on is convinced of the duty of Prayer, but it may be neglected; Oh then God will bring into danger to quicken to duty; Oh, Å¿ays God, In their affliction they will Å¿eek me early. The very Heathen Marriners called out for Prayer in time of danger. ObÅ¿erve it, that PerÅ¿ons convinced of duties, either PerÅ¿onal or DomeÅ¿tical, and yet neglected, God uÅ¿ually whips them to their Duties, by one danger, affliction or another. The Proverb is good, if you would teach a Man to Pray, Å¿end him to Sea. 2. God by bringing us into dangers, hath a deÅ¿ign upon us to convince us of Å¿in; many Convictions hath come into the Soul at this door; Dangers have often proved inlets to Convictions. Oh! What Convictions have many poor Souls lain under while in danger, when it may be the dangers hath
given them a view of Eternity; when Dangers hath preÅ¿ented Death to the Man, and ConÅ¿cience hath cried, Now thou art Å¿inking, now there is but a Å¿tep betwixt thee and Eternity, betwixt thee and another World? Oh then what Convictions hath the Soul lyen under? and yet it may be when the Danger is over, the Conviction is over too. Well, though we may forget all, yet God remembers all. 3. God hath a deÅ¿ign upon us in our Dangers, to prepare us for our latter end. The danger thou art in, and hath eÅ¿caped, calls for to prepare for thy Death, which muÅ¿t certainly come to paÅ¿s Å¿hortly. God by Dangers would have you prepare for Death: And Oh! VVhat a cutting ConÅ¿ideration will this be when thou com'Å¿t to die? that thou who haÅ¿t been in Å¿o many dangers by Sea and Land, Å¿hould have no more learned to die, nor ready to die. Alas, you eÅ¿caped the laÅ¿t, that you might prepare for the next. 4. God hath a deÅ¿ign upon our Graces by bringing us into danger; Danger is to exert and draw forth Grace. Thus the DiÅ¿ciples Dangers at Sea were to draw forth their Faith. Faith and Patience comes moÅ¿t viÅ¿ibly upon the Å¿tage in times of moÅ¿t eminent danger.
5. God by bringing us into Dangers, hath a deÅ¿ign upon our Souls; he Å¿ometimes by danger of drowning the Body, hath Å¿aved the Soul, and hath cauÅ¿ed it to Å¿ay, PeriiÅ¿Å¿em niÅ¿i periiÅ¿sem: I had periÅ¿hed, if I had not periÅ¿hed. Some have eÅ¿caped Shipwrack of Soul, by Shipwrack of Body; And Å¿hall we forget Å¿uch Dangers, when God hath Å¿uch gracious deÅ¿igns in them upon us?

2. He drives on gracious ends and deÅ¿igns in our Deliverances, And Å¿hall we then forget them? &c. 1. He Å¿pares us, that we may account his long-Å¿uffering Salvation; he gives, by Å¿paring of us, Å¿pace to Repent; and Oh! What ãâã dreadful thing is it not to remember wherefore we are Å¿pared and delivered? He gave her Å¿pace to Repent, but Å¿he repented not, PÅ¿al. 56. ult. The PriÅ¿oner is Reprieved, that he might Å¿ue out his Pardon, And will he forget the end for which he is Reprieved? 2. He delivers, that we may live to him. Why was David's feet deliver'd from falling? it was, that he might walk before the Lord in the light of the living. He gives us our lives, that we might give them back again to God, Jer. 7. 10. Men are not deliver'd from dangers to live to themÅ¿elves, to
live to their luÅ¿ts, to Drink, and Swear, and Rant, and Roar, as a great many poor Wretches do. That Å¿ay as they did, We are deliver'd to do all theÅ¿e abominations, PÅ¿al. 50. 15. 3. God hath another end in Deliverance, that we might glorifie him, in paying our Vows to him. I will deliver thee; And what then when out of Trouble never remember it more, caÅ¿t it behind thy back; O no; And thou Å¿halt glorifie me. He aims at a revenue of glory out of your deliverances. 4. God hath another end in delivering of us; that we might enter into New Engagements, to be more the Lords; as in times of great dangers, there uÅ¿e to be great engagements betwixt God and the Soul; Å¿o in times of Great Deliverances, there are great Engagements paÅ¿s betwixt God and the Soul, New Dedications to God; New Deliverances call for New Dedications of the Soul to God; now the Soul Å¿hould be Å¿et apart for God more than ever. 5. God hath another end in delivering of us, that we might break off our league with Å¿in; thus it was with them, Shall we break his Commandments, after Å¿uch great deliverance as this?

div.head: APPLICATION.
div.p: Is it Å¿o, that our Dangers and Deliverances Å¿hould be remembred by us? then it is a word of Information.

1. Learn we here how acceptable it is to God, that we thankfully congratulate our Mercies. No MuÅ¿ick like a Å¿ound of Trumpets off the VVaters: Å¿o, O what Å¿weet MuÅ¿ick doth it make in God's Eares, that you thankfully record Sea-Mercies, and Sea-Deliverances; this is MuÅ¿ick of the VVaters; this makes Melody in God's Eares. Sea-Prayers and Sea-PraiÅ¿es come up acceptably before the Lord; he is Å¿o pleaÅ¿ed with them, that he hath called them Sacrifices. O that Men would offer the Sacrifice of PraiÅ¿e; this is the found of Trumpets you Å¿hould carry to Sea with you, outward bound, and homeward bound.

2. Learn we hence what a Great Evil it is to loÅ¿e the remembrance of our Dangers and Deliverances. VVhat do many Families? VVhat do many PerÅ¿ons with the Sea-Dangers, with the Sea-Deliverances? Do not they write them in the duÅ¿t? Do not they bury them in the ãâã of Oblivion? Do not they caÅ¿t
them behind their backs? Do not they trample them under foot? O poor Souls! they little know what they do. 1. Such Deliverances will have a ReÅ¿urrection in their ConÅ¿ciences one day; though they bury them now, O they will riÅ¿e again: And Oh! How will they then dread and terrifie a poor Soul? 2. Such Deliverances will another day be witneÅ¿Å¿es and evidences againÅ¿t you. Oh! VVhat a cutting teÅ¿timony will they give in againÅ¿t the Soul? HaÅ¿t not thou been graciouÅ¿ly and wonderfully delivered in Å¿uch a Voyage, in Å¿uch a Storm at Sea, in Å¿uch a SickneÅ¿s at Shore, and yet walked unÅ¿uitably under all thefe? To be caÅ¿t out by mercy, O what a dreadful thing is this! 3. Such deliverances forgotten by us, harden us; either they Å¿often or harden. TheÅ¿e Providences are like God's Ordinances in this reÅ¿pect, they either harden or Å¿often. Oh! VVhat a dreadful thing it is to be harden'd by Deliverances and PreÅ¿ervation, and yet many are. Sentence being not Å¿peedily executed, the hearts of Men are fully Å¿et in them to do evil. 4. Such Deliverances will be Great aggravations both of man's Å¿in and miÅ¿ery, if forgotten by them. The goodneÅ¿s of God
was the aggravation of the Å¿in of David, Å¿ays God, When I had done Å¿o and Å¿o for thee, nay, and I would have done more, wherefore haÅ¿t thou deÅ¿piÅ¿ed the Commandment of the Lord, to do evil in his Å¿ight, 2 Sam. 12. 8, 9. VVhat, for you that had Å¿uch deliverances as theÅ¿e, to break his Commandment; as Ezra Å¿ays; O this is an high aggravation! 5. Deliverances and Dangers forgotten will cauÅ¿e the Lord to pull in his hand in a way of mercy, will cauÅ¿e God to give up PerÅ¿ons, and take his Protecting PreÅ¿ence from them, take them from the Å¿hadow of his VVings. Souls by forgetting paÅ¿t dangers and deliverances, may put themÅ¿elves from under God's Protection for the future.

Æ²Å¿e 2. Is it Å¿o that we are to Remember our Sea-dangers and deliverances? then it is a word of Exhortation; be exhorted then to call to mind, and keep in mind, what God hath done for you; and in this Exhortation I addreÅ¿s my Å¿elf to Sea-faring men, whoÅ¿e lives are a courÅ¿e and Å¿eries of VVonders in their frequent Salvations and PreÅ¿ervations, (witneÅ¿s this TreatiÅ¿e) as you Å¿ee the wonders of God in the Deeps, (viz.) The wonders of his Creation, Å¿o do you Å¿ee the wonders of his Salvation:
How often may Wonderful be Written upon the Head of Salvations that you are every Voyage receiving from God? you never go out, and come home, but God works Wonderfully, and appears Wonderfully for you; Is not he a Wonder-working-God for you every Voyage?

The Exhortation is to call to mind, and keep in mind, to Record and RegiÅ¿ter your Dangers and Deliverances, and not to do as IÅ¿rael is Å¿aid to do, who Å¿oon forgot his Works. How often doth God bring in this Å¿in of theirs in one PÅ¿alm? They forgot his works, and the wonders he had Å¿hewed them, PÅ¿al. 106. 13. PÅ¿al. 78. 11.

1. Keep them in mind, for they are wonderful Dangers and Deliverances; They are Wonders, theÅ¿e are to be remembred. Marvellous thin â¢ s did he for them, in the Å¿ight of their Fathers, &c. He devided the Sea, and cauÅ¿ed them to paÅ¿s through, and he made the waters to Å¿tand as an heap, PÅ¿al. 78. 12, 13. And it is brought in again in that PÅ¿alm. They remembred not his hand, nor the day when God delivered them out of the hand of the Ene â¢ y, &c. PÅ¿al.. 73. 42. And in another place, Th â¢ y forgot God their Saviour, which had done great things in Egypt,
Wondrous works in the Land of Ham, PÅ¿al. 106. 21. 22. This heightens the Å¿in exceedingly to forget Å¿uch Great and Wonderful Dangers and Deliverances.

1. Your Dangers are Wonderful in this ReÅ¿pect, they are often Å¿uch as threaten a Å¿entence of Death to be executed upon you. May it not be Å¿aid of poor Sea-men, as was of them; For we would not (Brethren) have you ignorant of our trouble, which came to us in AÅ¿ia, that we were preÅ¿Å¿ed out of meaÅ¿ure, above Å¿trength, inÅ¿omuch that we deÅ¿paired of Life, but we had the Å¿entence of death in our Å¿elves, that we Å¿hould not truÅ¿t in our Å¿elves, but in him that raiÅ¿eth the dead, who deliverid us from Å¿o great a Death, and doth Deliver, 2 Cor. 1. 8, 9, 10. O how many Sea-faring Men may Å¿ay thus! Our Dangers have been Å¿uch, as we have often deÅ¿paired of Life; there hath but been a little betwixt us and Death; nay, betwixt us and Eternity; And Å¿hall we forget Å¿uch dangers, when we have been Å¿o near death in them? As he Å¿aid to David, As the Lord lives, there is but one Å¿tep betwixt thee and death. O how often have you been near Å¿inking, near drowning, and yet God hath then appeared for you, with an outÅ¿tretched Arm, and in the
Mount hath been Å¿een, And will you not remember this?

2. Your Dangers are Wonderful in this ReÅ¿pect, they are Å¿udden and Å¿urprizing, they are wonderfully Å¿udden; How are you often, all on a Å¿udden, threatned with nothing but preÅ¿ent Death and DeÅ¿truction? It may be Å¿aid of Sea-men, as of thoÅ¿e in Job, Snares compaÅ¿Å¿es them about, and Å¿udden fear troubleth them, Job 22. 10. It doth not only trouble them, but all on a Å¿udden trouble them, before they know almoÅ¿t where they are (as we Å¿ay;) VVe read of Å¿ome whoÅ¿e Calamity Å¿hall come Å¿uddenly. Suddenly Å¿hall he be broken without Remedy, Prov. 6. 15. O how terrible is Å¿uch a caÅ¿e, or Å¿uch a danger And hath not God often threatned to make this your caÅ¿e and condition? O then do not forget Å¿uch dangers that have Å¿o Å¿uddenly lookt you in the Face!

3. Your Dangers are VVonderful in this ReÅ¿pect, they are not Dangers in which your Bodies are concerned only, but they are Dangers in which your Souls are concerned; It is not only the danger of a Ship-wrack'd VeÅ¿Å¿el, and a Ship-wrack'd EÅ¿tate, and a Shipwrack'd Body, but a Shipwrack'd Soul. Here
is the great danger, leÅ¿t thou make a loÅ¿t Voyage for thy Soul: If thou had died in Å¿uch a Storm, or died in the Term of Å¿uch a Voyage; Oh! VVhat would have become of thy Soul, thy precious, thy immortal Soul? Had not thou died in a Carnal, in a ChriÅ¿tleÅ¿s Å¿tate and condition? Had not thy poor Soul periÅ¿h'd to all Eternity, if thou then had miÅ¿carried? VVas not thou then a Å¿tranger altogether to ChriÅ¿t, and a VVork of Saving Grace upon thy Heart? Had not thou then the guilt of all thy Å¿ins upon the back of thy Soul unpardoned? And O what danger was this! And wilt thou forget Å¿uch dangers?

4. Your Dangers are Å¿uch at Sea, as none but a God can deliver from; all your skill cannot; O, then is the greateÅ¿t ArtiÅ¿t at his Wits end! The PÅ¿almiÅ¿t tells us, (PÅ¿al. 107. 27.) the Marriners in their Storms, are at their wits end; (or as Å¿ome read it) all their wiÅ¿dom is Å¿wallowed up, they know not what courÅ¿e to Steer, (the Dutch Annorators carry it,) Now their very Pilots are at a loÅ¿s; Now all their courage cannot contribute to their deliverance, though men of the greateÅ¿t natural courage and magnanimity in the world: Yet now their hearts melt
becauÅ¿e of troubles; as it is Å¿aid of the Marriners in Jonahs Ship, The Marriners were afraid. O now, when Death and Eternity, the Grave and Judgment to come looks them in the face! Then they are Magor-MiÅ¿Å¿abibs, terror to themÅ¿elves, and to all about them; O now, the danger is Å¿uch, it muÅ¿t be the only finger of God that can help! I have heard of a Ship in Yarmouth Road, that in a great Storm, they feared the Anchor would come home, and the MaÅ¿ter diÅ¿courÅ¿ing with a Youth in the Ship, that God had begun lately to work Å¿ome Convictions upon, O Å¿ays he, MaÅ¿ter if God do but lay a Finger upon one Strand of the Cable, it will hold; and in the morning many Ships were loÅ¿t near them, and there was but one Strand in the Cable left. O the finger of God only can Å¿ometimes Å¿ave in dangers. It was a good Å¿aying of a Godly Commander of a Ship in eminent dangers, None now but that God that Å¿aved the Children of IÅ¿rael at the Red Sea, can Å¿ave us out of this diÅ¿treÅ¿s; and as Å¿oon as he had Å¿aid it, the Wind altered, and Å¿aved them; And will you forget Å¿uch dangers as none but a God can Å¿ave from?

5. Your dangers at Sea are Å¿uch as many thouÅ¿ands have periÅ¿hed in; how many
have gone to Sea, that never returned more? that have been Å¿wallowed up in the belly of the great Deeps? How many have periÅ¿hed by the Sword at Sea? how many by violent Storms? and that God Å¿hould put a difference betwixt you and others, and you Å¿hould forget it, this exceedingly heightens and aggravates the guilt. How many have loÅ¿t their lives? how many have loÅ¿t their limbs? and yet in Å¿uch dangers God hath brought you off; this is never to be forgotten.

2. Your dangers are not only wonderful, but your deliverances are Å¿o too, and therefore Å¿hould be remembred. There is never a deliverance, but you may read a wonder in it; Å¿o many deliverances and Å¿alvations at Sea, Å¿o many wonders. God Å¿aves you in a miraculous way.

1. Is not this a wonder, that perÅ¿ons of Å¿uch great Å¿ins and provocations, Å¿hould be perÅ¿ons of Å¿uch great Å¿alvations and preÅ¿ervations? that Å¿uch as Å¿in every Voyage, nay, it may be at an high rate Å¿in every Voyage, Å¿hould be Å¿aved and delivered at Å¿uch an high rate every Voyage? is not this a wonder, that men of Å¿uch Å¿ins, Å¿hould be men of Å¿uch Å¿alvations? that men that Å¿in againÅ¿t theÅ¿e Å¿alvations, Å¿hould not have theÅ¿e deliverances Å¿horten
upon them. Oh what a wonder is this! We Å¿hould wonder if a perÅ¿on Å¿hould be continually diÅ¿obliging any of us, and yet we Å¿hould be Å¿till heaping up kindneÅ¿Å¿es upon him: This made the Prophet Ezra Å¿ay, Shall we again break his Commandments, after Å¿uch deliverance as this? O do not you provoke the Lord every time that you go out, and Å¿till he delivers you, Å¿till he returns you to your Relations, to viÅ¿it your habitations in peace! and is not this a wonder?

2. Your deliverances are wonderful, if you conÅ¿ider your deliverances are great deliverances. We read of Å¿uch; And the Lord Å¿aved them with a great deliverance; or with a great Å¿alvation. Thus Å¿aid SampÅ¿on, Thou haÅ¿t given this great deliverance into the hand of thy Å¿ervant, (Judg. 15. 18.) Now any great tranÅ¿actions are remembred and recorded. Your deliverances are great, if we conÅ¿ider theÅ¿e things; 1. They are commanded deliverances by the great God; his word of command brings all our deliverances about, whether at Sea or Land. Which made the Church in diÅ¿treÅ¿s pray, Thou art my King, O God, command deliverances for Jacob, (PÅ¿al. 44. 4.) He commands every thing tending to deliverance at Sea; in order to deliverance, he commands
the Winds; He maketh the Å¿torm a calm, (PÅ¿al. 107. 29.) He alÅ¿o commands the Seas; he Å¿ays to the proud Waves, So far, and no farther. You read of a decree Å¿et to the Sea, that it cannot paÅ¿s; Though the Waves thereof toÅ¿s themÅ¿elves, yet can they not prevail; though they roar, yet can they not paÅ¿s over it, (Jer. 5. 22.) It is the great God only that rides Lord Admiral at Sea, to command the Seas and the Waves thereof. God is Å¿aid to Å¿hut up the Sea with doors, and Å¿et bars upon it. Hitherto Å¿halt thou come, and no further; and here Å¿hall thy proud waves be Å¿tayed, (Job. 38. 8, 11.) Xerxes preÅ¿umed he could tame the HelleÅ¿pont, for attempting his Bridge of Boats; but all this was in vain, this is a flower in Gods Crown alone, to command the Sea. Your deliverances are a fruit and effect of Gods commanding Power, therefore great. 2. They are great deliverances, as they are the curious workmanÅ¿hip (as I may call them) of the Attributes of a great God. Deliverance is Å¿aid to be wrought for us, it is the handy work of God; If God will work, who can let? (as the Prophet Å¿aith, IÅ¿a. 43. 13, 14.) And he Å¿eems to Å¿peak it upon the account of the deliverance of his People; For your Å¿ake I have Å¿ent down to Babylon, and have
brought down all their Nobles, and the Caldeans, whoÅ¿e cry is in their Å¿hips. In every deliverance there is the excellent work of the Attributes of God; we may in Å¿uch a deliverance Å¿ay, Here is the Power of God, and here is the WiÅ¿dom of God, and here is the Love of God, and here is the FaithfulneÅ¿s of God, &c. For as God in the confounding of the Languages at Babel, Å¿aid, Go too, let us go down, (as if he derected himÅ¿elf to his glorious Attributes, compaÅ¿Å¿ing about his glorious Throne) Come, let us go down. Gen. 11. 7. (Or, as Å¿ome take it of the Trinity, as in the Creation.) So when God Å¿ends us deliverances in our diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿es, he Å¿ets his Attributes at work; Go Power, go Mercy, go Love, go FaithfulneÅ¿s, go and act your reÅ¿pective parts in this deliverance; and muÅ¿t not this be then an excellent and curious Piece that Gods Attributes bring forth? 3. They are great deliverances, if we conÅ¿ider the great Å¿ins and provocations they come over the heads of, the great unworthineÅ¿s of the receiver, heightens much the mercy and favour received; the reaÅ¿on why perÅ¿ons do not greaten their deliverances, is becauÅ¿e they do not greaten their Å¿ins, in the deep Å¿enÅ¿e and aggravations of them.
O Å¿uch a Soul would Å¿ay, as David, Is this the manner of men? O God, is not this a great deliverance for Å¿uch a great Å¿inner to receive? 4. They are great deliverances, if we conÅ¿ider the time and Å¿eaÅ¿on of their coming in; as this deliverance of the Ships Company where Paul was, it was when all hope of being Å¿aved was taken away; and Å¿o were many of the deliverances mentioned in this TreatiÅ¿e. So Peter's Sea-deliverance, when he began to Å¿ink, ChriÅ¿t Å¿tretched forth his hand immediately; he was now Å¿inking and going, but Å¿ee how ready ChriÅ¿t was to Å¿ave; He Å¿tretched forth his hand and caught Peter, (Matth. 14. 28, 29, 30.) Our Å¿inking time, is JeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿ts Å¿aving time. In the Mount is the Lord Å¿een; our extremity is Gods opportunity; and are not then theÅ¿e great deliverances never to be forgotten? 5. They are great deliverances, if we conÅ¿ider they are not only deliverances of Bodies, and Ships, and EÅ¿tates Å¿ometimes, but Souls; and where the Ship is loÅ¿t, and the EÅ¿tate is loÅ¿t, yet for the life to be Å¿aved, and the Soul delivered, is a very great Deliverance; a Reprieve when a PriÅ¿oner is under the Å¿entence of Death, is a great Mercy: O when God Reprieves a poor PriÅ¿oner,
this is Å¿ome Deliverance; we read o â¢ Å¿ome Deliverance God gave to IÅ¿rael in the days of ShiÅ¿hak; a Reprieve is Å¿ome Deliverance, but if it end in Å¿uing out the PriÅ¿oners Pardon, then it is a great Deliverance. If it be Å¿uch a Deliverance in a Storm at Sea, as Hezekiah had from a SickneÅ¿s at Shoar, Thou haÅ¿t delivered me in love to my Soul, and caÅ¿t all my Å¿ins behind thy back, (IÅ¿a. 38.) This is a double Deliverance, and Å¿ure Å¿uch Deliverances as theÅ¿e are worth Recording; TheÅ¿e are to be written in Marble and not in DuÅ¿t, with the Pen of Iron, (as the Prophet Å¿ays) and not with with point of a Diamond.

3. Your Deliverances are wonderful, if you conÅ¿ider the many thouÅ¿ands that have periÅ¿hed in leÅ¿s Dangers to an eye of ReaÅ¿on; they are diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hing Deliverances, and therefore wonderful hath God dealt with all men that go to Sea as with you. Hath not thouÅ¿ands periÅ¿hed by the Sword at Sea in bloody Engagements? MiÅ¿carried at Sea in dreadful and terrible Storms; Hath not the Sea been a Sepulcher for thouÅ¿ands? Are not there Millions of the Dead that the Sea muÅ¿t one day give up, and yet you Delivered, and yet you Å¿pared? O what diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hing Mercy is this! And Å¿hall this be forgotten
by you? Should not you keep Records of diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hing Mercy? How many Å¿unk Å¿ometimes, and periÅ¿hed by your Å¿ides? How many that went out with you that never Returned? One taken, and another left; one Å¿unk, and another Å¿aved.

4. Your Deliverances are Wonderful, if you conÅ¿ider the way that Å¿ometimes God takes to bring them about; O what Å¿trange ways doth God take to deliver, when he hath a mind to deliver; Å¿ometimes he brings down to the very Gate of the Grave, he brings to the Doors and Bars of the Sea, and then Å¿huts theÅ¿e doors; as Job Å¿peaks, He brings to the next door to periÅ¿hing, and then he delivers; MaÅ¿ter Å¿ave me, or I periÅ¿h; and then he lends an Arm, witneÅ¿s many of theÅ¿e deliverances here mentioned. Sometimes he doth it by Å¿trange means, low and contemptible, as the poor man that we Read of, that delivered the City, (EccleÅ¿. 9. 15.) Å¿ometimes by unthought of and unexpected means, as he that Relieved Major Gibbons, as this Story mentions, he was a French Pyrate. As that Ship I have heard off, that when Å¿he Å¿prang a Leak, and they all had like to have periÅ¿hed, all on a Å¿udden the Leak Å¿topt, and they knew no ReaÅ¿on, but when they
came into the next Port to Å¿earch her, there was a great FiÅ¿h had wrought himÅ¿elf into the Leak, that they were glad to cut him out; was not here a miraculous deliverance? That Jonah Å¿hould be Å¿wallowed up by the Whale, O what a miracle was this! and Å¿o he was preÅ¿erved! and how have Å¿ome been Å¿aved by Å¿udden Å¿hifts of Winds when near Å¿inking and periÅ¿hing? theÅ¿e are to be remembred to the Lord while you live: Oh! methinks this one Motive Å¿hould Å¿et on the Exhortation, if I Å¿hould uÅ¿e no more, to Remember your Dangers and your Deliverances.

But Å¿econdly, another Motive is this, to Remember your Dangers with your Deliverances; this will in your great diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿es and extremities, contribute Å¿ome hope to you; to read over your RegiÅ¿ter, your ancient Records, how good God hath been at Å¿uch a time, and Å¿uch a time; how Å¿eaÅ¿onably he Å¿tept in and delivered in Å¿uch a Å¿trait and Å¿uch a Å¿trait; Oh then Å¿ays the Soul, why Å¿hould I deÅ¿pair, and caÅ¿t off all hope now? hath not he appeared and Å¿aved in Deaths often before now? for paÅ¿t experiences are good Å¿upports for Hope in preÅ¿ent exigencies and extremities; thus David argues, when at a great Å¿trait, Thou haÅ¿t delivered me, and
wilt deliver me; and thus Paul, Thou haÅ¿t delivered me, and wilt deliver me. Haman found this a good way to Remember the years of the Lords right hand.

3. Remember your Dangers and Deliverances, for God Records them; they are filled up by God, and he will mind you of them another day if you forget them now; he keeps his Journals and Records; he hath his Book of Remembrance of your forgotten Mercies, as well as your forgotten Å¿ins; God will one day read over all thoÅ¿e Deliverances you have forgotten; Oh poor Soul! did not I deliver thee in Å¿uch a Danger, in Å¿uch a DiÅ¿treÅ¿s, in Å¿uch a Death, when there was no Hope, when there was no Help, yet all this haÅ¿t thou forgotten; forgotten thy Mercy, and forgotten the God of thy Mercy; Oh! will not this Å¿ting you to the Heart, when God Å¿hall cauÅ¿e your Å¿trangled, and murdered Mercies to walk in your ConÅ¿ciences? when he Å¿hall give them a ReÅ¿urrection there?

4. Motive to Remember your Dangers and Deliverances: the Vows of God are upon you; Oh! what did you Å¿ay to God in the day of your diÅ¿treÅ¿s and calamity? Lord, if thou wilt now appear, and be a preÅ¿ent help in time of trouble, it Å¿hall

never be forgotten, i â¢ Å¿hall be remembred to the Lord as long as we have a day to live; but when God brings poor Souls off, many do not only forget their Vows, but deny them; In Ancient times it was uÅ¿ual in eminent dangers, whether at Sea or Land, to make Vows; We read that Jonahs Mariners they Vowed Vows, (Jonah 1. 16.) David did thus, Thy Vows are upon me, O God! I will render praiÅ¿es unto thee, &c. PÅ¿al. 56 11. (and in another place) I will pay thee my Vows, which my lips have uttered, and my mouth hath Å¿poken when I was in trouble, (PÅ¿al. 66. 13, 14.) But becauÅ¿e this is Å¿o ordinary to make Vows at Sea, and brake them a Shoar, let me enlarge a little upon it. 1. Why Å¿hould you forget your Vows after your Deliverances? They were not raÅ¿h Vows, there might have been Å¿ome excuÅ¿e, if you had made them raÅ¿hly, you might then have had a Plea, for Å¿aying it was an Error; but in times of diÅ¿treÅ¿s, men are Å¿erious, when Death and Eternity is Å¿et before them, and they upon the brink of another world; dare you Å¿inners raÅ¿hly Vow, in this day of your diÅ¿treÅ¿s; O no, your ConÅ¿ciences will bear witneÅ¿s againÅ¿t you, that you were in Å¿ober-Å¿adneÅ¿s at that day. 2. Why Å¿hould you
forget your Vows after your Deliverances, for God will require payment?
